courses.title: University Mathematics

Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03

courses.description:
This course is intended for students who need to acquire the knowledge and skills of one-variable calculus at a general level for the studies in mathematics, science, engineering and other areas. The course places special emphasis on conceptual understanding and computational techniques.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH1018 or students who are taking MATH1520 in the same term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to be able to:
• Define and distinguish the usual concepts used in one variable calculus
• Logically prove basic statements in one variable calculus
• Calculate various differential quantities and solve problems using one variable calculus
• Apply the methods of one variable calculus to standard problems in physics, engineering, or business economics
• Appreciate the rationale and impact of one variable calculus to human development in science and technology.
courses.course_syllabus: Limits, derivatives, linear approximation, curve sketching, mean value theorem, L'Hospital's rule, Taylor’s theorem, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration.
courses.recommended_readings:
• Calculus of One Variable, K.E. Hirst, Springer-Verlag
• Edwards and Penny, Calculus: Early Transcendentals
• Thomas and Finney, Calculus and Analytical Geometry

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Honours University Mathematics
courses.description:
This course is intended for MATH major students who need to acquire the knowledge and skills of one-variable calculus at an advanced level. The course places special emphasis on theoretical foundations and techniques for computations.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH1010 or students who are taking MATH1520 in the same term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• Define and distinguish the usual concepts used in one variable calculus.
• Logically prove basic statements in one variable calculus.
• Calculate various differential quantities and solve problems using one variable calculus
• Apply the methods of one variable calculus to standard problems in physics, engineering, or business economics.
• Appreciate the rationale and impact of one variable calculus to human development in science and technology.
courses.course_syllabus: Limits, derivatives, linear approximation, curve sketching, mean value theorem, L'Hospital's rule, Taylor’s theorem, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration; constructions of certain basic functions of one variable, and mechanisms of the proofs of various theorems as appropriate
courses.recommended_readings:
- Calculus of One Variable, K.E. Hirst, Springer-Verlag
- Edwards and Penny, Calculus: Early Transcendentals
- Thomas and Finney, Calculus and Analytical Geometry

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: General Mathematics
courses.description:
This course is designed to give students a solid foundation for learning calculus and other areas of mathematics in engineering.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: MATH1020
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should be able to

• understand the basics of functions.

• recognize different types of elementary functions, their graphs, know their properties and solve related equations.

• understand topics in vectors, series and power series, complex numbers and probability and perform related computations.

• develop a solid foundation to study mathematics in other areas of engineering.
courses.course_syllabus: Sets and functions, polynomial and rational functions, trigonometric functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, series and power series, complex numbers, vectors and probability.
courses.recommended_readings: Michael Sullivan, Michael Sullivan III, Precalculus: enhanced with graphing utilities, 6th Edition, Pearson, 2013.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Essential Mathematical Methods

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803

courses.description:
This course is designed as a continuation of the HKDSE Mathematics (Compulsory Part) or equivalent, to familiarize mathematics major students with elementary and foundational algebraic and geometric methods which will help the study of other MATH courses.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH1028, 1050/1058 or students who are taking MATH1525 in the same term. Co-requisite: MATH1010/1018.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students are able to:

* Understand the content of simple mathematical statements.
* Apply various results about elementary algebraic methods and geometric methods in simple computational type problems.
* Deduce, with reference of definitions, (but if relevant and necessary, with various established classical results assumed) simple mathematical results in elementary algebra, such as divisibility (for integers), inequalities (about real numbers), complex numbers, polynomials and their roots.
* Read off and describe solutions of simple equations and inequalities through the use of algebraic methods, and/or graphical methods.
* Handle simple geometric problems with algebraic methods, and visualize simple algebraic problems through geometry.
courses.course_syllabus: Summation and product notations, set notations (including the description of sets through specification), divisibility for integers, rationals and irrationals, surds, laws of indices, inequalities about real numbers, absolute value, algebra of complex numbers and the Argand plane, polynomials and their roots, Binomial Theorem, solving (algebraic-type) equations and inequalities (with elementary algebraic means), classical inequalities, simple infinite sequences and series, exponentiation and logarithm, trigonometric functions, coordinate geometry in two/three dimensions, vector geometry in two/three dimensions, basic methods of mathematical argument (such as direct proof, mathematical induction, proof-by-contradiction argument, dis-proof) through concrete examples.
courses.recommended_readings:
* K. T. Leung, P. H. Cheung: Fundamental Concepts of Mathematics.
* K. T. Leung, I. A. C. Mok, S. N. Suen: Polynomials and Equations.
* K. T. Leung, S. N. Suen: Vectors, Matrices and Geometry.
* William Briggs, G. H. Bryan: The Tutorial Algebra (Volumes I, II).
* S. L. Green: Advanced Level Pure Mathematics.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Honours Essential Mathematical Methods
courses.description:
This course is designed as a continuation of the HKDSE Mathematics (Compulsory Part) or equivalent, to familiarize mathematics major students with foundational algebraic and geometric methods which will help in the study of other MATH courses (including Honours courses).
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH1025, 1050/1058 or students who are taking MATH1525 in the same term. Co-requisite: MATH1018.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students are able to:

* Understand the content of simple mathematical statements.
* Apply various results about elementary algebraic methods and geometric methods in computational type problems.
* Deduce, with reference of definitions, (but if relevant and necessary, with various established classical results assumed) mathematical results in elementary algebra, such as divisibility (for integers), inequalities (about real numbers), complex numbers, polynomials and their roots.
* Read off and describe solutions of simple equations and inequalities through the use of algebraic methods, and/or graphical methods.
* Handle simple geometric problems with algebraic methods, and visualize simple algebraic problems through geometry.
courses.course_syllabus: Summation and product notations, set notations (including the description of sets through specification), divisibility for integers, rationals and irrationals, surds, laws of indices, inequalities about real numbers, absolute value, algebra of complex numbers and the Argand plane, polynomials and their roots, Binomial Theorem, solving (algebraic-type) equations and inequalities (with elementary algebraic means), classical inequalities, simple infinite sequences and series, exponentiation and logarithm, trigonometric functions, coordinate geometry in two/three dimensions, vector geometry in two/three dimensions, basic methods of mathematical argument (such as direct proof, mathematical induction, proof-by-contradiction argument, dis-proof) through concrete examples.
courses.recommended_readings:
* K. T. Leung, P. H. Cheung: Fundamental Concepts of Mathematics.
* K. T. Leung, I. A. C. Mok, S. N. Suen: Polynomials and Equations.
* K. T. Leung, S. N. Suen: Vectors, Matrices and Geometry.
* William Briggs, G. H. Bryan: The Tutorial Algebra (Volumes I, II).
* S. L. Green: Advanced Level Pure Mathematics.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Linear Algebra I

meetings.location: Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE
Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE
Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE

courses.description:
This course is intended for students who need to acquire the knowledge and skills of linear algebra. The course emphasizes the fundamental principles, reasoning of mathematics and also applications, but generality instead of particular usage will be the focus.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH1038 or students who are taking MATH1550 in the same term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to
- define and distinguish the usual concepts used in linear algebra
- logically prove basic statements in linear algebra
- solve problems using linear algebra, including those in an abstract setting
- apply the methods of linear algebra to standard problems in physics, engineering, or business economics
- appreciate the rationale and impact of linear algebra to human development in science and technology
courses.course_syllabus: Set notations; system of linear equations, Gaussian elimination; matrices, determinants; Euclidean vector spaces, subspaces, linear span, linear independence, bases and dimension; eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization; orthogonality, Gram-Schmidt process.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Leon, Linear Algebra with Applications
- Johnson, Riess, Arnold, Introduction to Linear Algebra

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Honours Linear Algebra I
courses.description:
This course is intended as the first course on linear algebra for MATH major students. The course emphasizes the fundamental concepts and principles in linear algebra, and focuses on rigorous reasoning of mathematical statements, computational techniques as well as applications.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students who have taken MATH1030 or students who are taking MATH1550 in the same term. Pre-requisite: [Alternative 1] Grade B- or above in each of MATH1018, 1028.
[Alternative 2] Grade A- or above in each of MATH1010, 1025.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to
- define and distinguish the usual concepts used in linear algebra
- logically prove basic statements in linear algebra and understand ideas behind the proofs of theorems
- solve problems using linear algebra, including those in an abstract setting
- apply the methods of linear algebra to standard problems in physics, engineering, or business economics
- appreciate the rationale and impact of linear algebra to human development in science and technology
courses.course_syllabus: Set notations; system of linear equations, Gaussian elimination; matrices, determinants; Euclidean and abstract vector spaces, subspaces, linear span, linear independence, bases and dimension; definition and examples of linear transformations; eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization; orthogonality, Gram-Schmidt process.
courses.recommended_readings:
- G. Strang: Linear algebra and applications
- S. Friedberg, A. Insel, L. Spence: Linear algebra

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Foundation of Modern Mathematics
courses.description:
This course introduces rigorous mathematical reasoning, and proofs. The use of logic in mathematics and various methods of proof will be illustrated by concrete examples from a variety of topics in mathematics.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH1025/1028, 1058, 1090/1098. Pre-requisite: MATH1010 or MATH1018 or (Grade B or above in MATH1510 or MATH1520). Co-requisite: MATH1030 or MATH1038 or ENGG1410 or ESTR1004 or ENGG1120 or ESTR1005.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• Read and write mathematical statements.
• Prove simple mathematical results in various topics, such as number theory, inequalities, polynomials, complex numbers, set language.
• Understand the basic properties of number systems, and infinite sets.
courses.course_syllabus: Mathematical statements, sets, relations and functions, infinite sets and countability, natural numbers and induction, integers, rational, real and complex numbers, elementary inequalities.
courses.recommended_readings:
• Binmore, K.G.: Logic, Sets and Numbers
• Bloch E.D.: Proofs and Fundamentals: a first course in abstract mathematics
• Briggs W., Bryan, G.H. Walker G.: The Tutorial Algebra (Vol. I, II)
• Halmos P.R.: Naïve Set Theory.
• Leung K.T., Chan D.L.C.: Elementary Set Theory
• Leung K.T., Cheung P.H.: Fundamental Concepts of Mathematics

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Honours Foundation of Modern Mathematics
courses.description:
This course introduces rigorous mathematical reasoning, and proofs. The use of logic in mathematics and various methods of proof will be illustrated by concrete examples from a variety of topics in mathematics.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students who have taken MATH1025/1028, 1050, 1090/1098.
Pre-requisite: [Alternative 1] B- or above in each of MATH1018, MATH1038. [Alternative 2] A- or above in each of MATH1010, 1030.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• Read and write mathematical statements.
• Prove rigorously simple mathematical results in various topics, such as number theory, inequalities, polynomials, complex numbers, set theory.
• Understand (including through the axiomatic approach) the basic properties of number systems, and infinite sets.
courses.course_syllabus: Mathematical statements, sets, relations and functions, infinite sets and countability, natural numbers and induction, integers, rational, real and complex numbers, elementary inequalities, rudiments of various axiomatic systems (for, such as, set theory, geometry, algebra).
courses.recommended_readings:
• Binmore, K.G.: Logic, Sets and Numbers
• Bloch E.D.: Proofs and Fundamentals: a first course in abstract mathematics
• Briggs W., Bryan, G.H. Walker G.: The Tutorial Algebra (Vol. I, II)
• Halmos P.R.: Naïve Set Theory.
• Kadison L, Kromann M.T.: Projective Geometry and Modern Algebra
• Leung K.T., Chan D.L.C.: Elementary Set Theory
• Leung K.T., Cheung P.H.: Fundamental Concepts of Mathematics

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Introduction to Set Theory
courses.description:
This course introduces the language of sets, and through the use of sets, relations, functions in various concrete examples from a variety of topics in mathematics, introduces the use of logic in rigorous reasoning and abstract thinking. Topics are selected amongst: logic and axiomatic systems; sets, relations and functions; numbers and polynomials, and various algebraic structures; construction of number systems; infinite sets.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students who have taken MATH1050/1058/1098.
Pre-requisite:[Option 1] MATH1010/1018 or (Grade B or above in MATH1510/1520) or (Grade A- or above in ENGG1125/ESTR1007) with co-requisite MATH1025/1028 & 1030/1038.
Check dept website for more options
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:

* Comprehend and formulate simple mathematical statements that involve the use of sets, relations and functions.
* Prove simple mathematical statements that involve the use of sets, relations and functions.
* Understand the basic properties of various number systems (from the point of view of construction through the use of sets, relations and functions), simple algebraic structures, and infinite sets.
courses.course_syllabus: Statements and predicates, logical connectives and quantifiers, sets, relations and functions, infinite sets and countability, the natural number system and the Principle of Mathematical Induction, the systems of integers, rationals, real numbers and complex numbers, algebraic structures.
courses.recommended_readings:
* Binmore K.G.: Logic, Sets and Numbers.
* Bloch E.D.: Proofs and Fundamentals: a first course in abstract mathematics.
* Schumacher C.: Chapter Zero: fundamental notions of abstract mathematics.
* Halmos P.R.: Naïve Set Theory.
* Leung K.T., Chan D.L.C.: Elementary Set Theory.
* Stewart I., Tall, D.: The Foundations of Mathematics.
* Lipschutz S.: Schaum’s outline of Theory and Problems of Set Theory and Related Topics.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Honours Introduction to Set Theory
courses.description:
This course introduces the language of sets, and through the use of sets, relations, functions in various concrete examples from a variety of topics in mathematics, introduces the use of logic in rigorous reasoning and abstract thinking. Topics are selected amongst: logic and axiomatic systems; sets, relations and functions; numbers and polynomials, and various algebraic structures; construction of number systems; infinite sets.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students who have taken MATH1050/1058 or MATH1090. 
Pre-requisite: [Alternative 1]: Grade B- or above in each of MATH1018, 1028. [Alternative 2]: Grade A- or above in each of MATH1010, 1025. Co-requisite: MATH1030/1038.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:

* Comprehend and formulate mathematical statements that involve the use of sets, relations and functions.
* Prove mathematical statements that involve the use of sets, relations and functions.
* Understand the properties of various number systems (from the point of view of construction through the use of sets, relations and functions), simple algebraic structures, and infinite sets.
courses.course_syllabus: Statements and predicates, logical connectives and quantifiers, sets, relations and functions, infinite sets and countability, the natural number system and the Principle of Mathematical Induction, the systems of integers, rationals, real numbers and complex numbers, algebraic structures.
courses.recommended_readings:
* Binmore K.G.: Logic, Sets and Numbers.
* Bloch E.D.: Proofs and Fundamentals: a first course in abstract mathematics.
* Schumacher C.: Chapter Zero: fundamental notions of abstract mathematics.
* Halmos P.R.: Naïve Set Theory.
* Leung K.T., Chan D.L.C.: Elementary Set Theory.
* Stewart I., Tall, D.: The Foundations of Mathematics.
* Lipschutz S.: Schaum’s outline of Theory and Problems of Set Theory and Related Topics.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Calculus for Engineers
courses.description: This course is designed for engineering students who need to acquire skills in calculus as a crash introduction to the mathematics used in engineering. The course emphasizes on the technique of computation without theoretical discussion. Students are expected to have mathematics background equivalent to HKDSE with Extended Module I or II.
courses.enrollment_requirement: MATH1510
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will learn the aspects of single variable Calculus that apply to engineering applications. They will also have an exposure to some applications of single variable Calculus in engineering and physics.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Transcendental functions (exponential, logarithm, trigonometric and their inverses).

2. Curves represented by parametric equations.

3. Differentiation in single variable calculus (basic rules, implicit differentiation, rate of change, approximation, L’Hospital's Rule, extreme values and curve sketching).

4. Vector valued functions and their differentiation rules.

5. Integration in single variable calculus (definite and indefinite integrals, techniques of integration, area and volume of revolution).

6. Series (Taylor expansion, Taylor and Maclaurin series, techniques involving power series and Taylor’s theorem).
courses.recommended_readings:
• T. Croft, R. Davison: Mathematics for Engineers, A modern interactive approach, 2nd ed., Prentice Hall

• C. Edwards, D. Penney: Calculus, Early Transcendentals, Matrix Version, 6th ed., Prentice Hall

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: University Mathematics for Applications
courses.description: This course is intended for students who need to acquire the knowledge and skills of one-variable calculus at a general level for the studies in science, technology and other areas. The course emphasizes the methods and techniques of computation and their applications, with appropriate discussions on theoretical foundation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH1010/1018.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to
- Define and distinguish the usual concepts used in calculus
- Calculate differential and integral quantities in one variable calculus
- Apply calculus to solve problems in science, technology and other areas
- Appreciate the rationale and use of one variable calculus in the development of science, technology and other areas
courses.course_syllabus: Elementary functions, limit and continuity of functions, differentiation, indefinite and definite integration, ordinary differential equations and their applications.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Barnett et al, Applied Calculus for Business, Economics, Life Sciences, and Social Sciences
- Hoffmann, Bradley, Applied Calculus for Business, Economics, Social Sciences and Life Sciences

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Basic Mathematics for Science and Technology
courses.description: This course is designed as a continuation of the HKDSE Mathematics (Compulsory Part) or equivalent, to give students who intend to study general science subjects a solid foundation for the use of basic mathematics in various disciplines in physical science, life science and statistics, and for the study of the applications of calculus and linear algebra in science and technology.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken any one of MATH1010/1018, MATH1025/1028, MATH1530.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students are able to:

* recognize and handle elementary mathematical entities appearing in physical science, life science and statistics.
* apply elementary algebraic and graphical methods in modelling and/or solving problems in physical science, life science, and statistics.
* manipulate with algebraic entities and simple inequalities logically.
courses.course_syllabus: Summation and product notations, simple algebra expressions and basic algebraic methods (about identities, equations, inequalities concerned with real numbers), simple infinite sequences and series, exponentiation and logarithm, trigonometric functions, rectangular and polar coordinates, simple matrices and complex numbers, straightforward verification of identities and simple inequalities, method of mathematical induction.
courses.recommended_readings:
* Graham Doggett, Martin Cockett: Maths for Chemists.
* David Phoenix: Introductory Mathematics for the Life Sciences.
* Sally Jordan, Shelagh Ross, Pat Murphy: Maths for Science.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Basic Mathematics for Business and Social Sciences
courses.description: This course equips students with the necessary basic mathematics for applications in business and social sciences. It is particularly suitable for those without much mathematics training in high school. Concepts will be introduced by examples in these disciplines.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken any one of MATH1010/1018, MATH1025/1028, MATH1030/1038, MATH1525, MATH2xxx or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• Acquire mathematical skills beyond school level.
• Apply elementary mathematics to solve simple problems in business and social sciences.
• Appreciate the rationale and impact of mathematics to human development in business and social sciences.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include: linear equations, matrices, linear programming, counting and probability, mathematics of finance, modelling in mathematics.
courses.recommended_readings:
• Biggs N, Anthony M: Mathematics for Economics and Finance
• Liall M L, Greenwell R N, Ritchey N P: Finite Mathematics and Calculus with Applications.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: University Mathematics for Financial Studies
courses.description: This course is designed for students who wish to specialize in mathematics related financial studies. It is especially suitable for those who have a mathematics background similar to that of HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module I or II. The students are to acquire further cognition and stronger skills from their original training. It leads to the command of knowledge and operation of higher algebra. By this course, the students will have a smooth transition into studying the essential mathematics for financial studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MATH1010.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:

• Write mathematical argument inductively and deductively

• Perform matrix operations, calculate determinants, find inverses and solve equations in such context

• Perform usual work involving partial differentiation and multiple integrals

• Appreciate the rationale and impact of pure mathematics to human development in business and technology.
courses.course_syllabus: Foundation of mathematics, matrix algebra and linear equations, calculus of several variable
courses.recommended_readings:
• Kolman and Hill, Introductory Linear Algebra with Applications

• Thomas, Weir, and Hass, Thomas’ Calculus

• Edwards and Penny, Calculus: Early Transcendentals

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Methods of Matrices and Linear Algebra

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404

courses.description: This course is intended as an introduction to elementary linear algebra through a matrix oriented approach. Its content emphasizes on the methods and techniques for the acquisition of basic understanding and calculation skills in various elementary topics in linear algebra (such as matrix operations, systems of linear equations, determinants, orthogonality, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, linear transformations). The course is suitable for students without much mathematics background and intended to be major in Statistics, Economics, Business, Life Sciences and Social Sciences.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH1030/1038.
courses.course_syllabus: Matrix and vector notations, systems of linear equations and Gaussian elimination, linear independence of row/column vectors; matrix operations and inverse, cofactor expansion and properties of determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization, orthogonal vectors and Gram-Schmidt process, orthogonal projection and least-square method, subspaces in Euclidean space, basis and dimension, matrix transformations.
courses.recommended_readings:
L.E. Spence, A.J. Insel, S.H. Friedberg. Elementary Linear Algebra, Pearson.
C.H. Edwards, D.E. Penney. Elementary Linear Algebra, Pearson.
B. Kolman, D. Hill. Elementary Linear Algebra with Applications, Pearson.
H. Anton. Elementary Linear Algebra, Wiley.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Linear Algebra for Advanced Accounting Analytics
courses.description: This course is intended as a non-technical introduction to the use of linear algebra in business, economics, finance, and accounting. Its content emphasizes on intuitive understanding of concepts and methods in linear algebra, and their applications in various branches of modern technology relevant to business, economics, finance, and accounting.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH1010/1018 or 1025/1028 or 1030/1038 or 1510 or 1520 or 1525 or 1530 or 1550.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students are able to:

* Understand the basic terminologies and notations in linear algebra.
* Perform simple manipulations concerned with matrix, vector, determinant, inner product and norm.
* Identify, in concrete situations, properties and constructions associated with individual matrices and vectors, or collections of matrices and vectors.
courses.course_syllabus:
Matrix and vector algebra, determinant, linear combination, linear dependence and linear independence, linear transformation, null space and span, basis and dimension, rank, R^n as an inner product space, the Euclidean norm and orthogonality, eigenvalue and eigenvector.

Optional advanced topics: pseudo-inverse, matrix decompositions (such as LU-decomposition, QR-decomposition, SV-decomposition).
courses.recommended_readings:
* David C. Lay, Steven R. Lay, Judi J. McDonald: Linear Algebra and Its Applications (any edition).
* Steven J. Leon: Linear Algebra with Applications (any edition).
* Gilbert Strang: Linear Algebra and Its Applications (any edition).

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Calculus for Advanced Accounting Analytics
courses.description: This course is intended as a non-technical introduction to the use of calculus of one and several variables in business, economics, finance, and accounting. Its content emphasizes on intuitive understanding of concepts and methods in calculus, and their applications in various branches of modern technology relevant to business, economics, finance, and accounting.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH1010/1018 or 1025/1028 or 1030/1038 or 1510 or 1525 or 1530 or 1550.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students are able to:

* Understand the basic terminologies and notations in calculus of one and several variables.
* Perform simple manipulations concerned with limit, derivative, partial derivative, integral and double integral.
* Identify, in concrete situations, properties and constructions associated with limit, derivative, partial derivative, integral and double integral.
courses.course_syllabus:
Differential calculus for functions of one variable: limit and derivative, higher-order derivatives, product rule and quotient rule, chain rule, rate of change, application of derivatives in optimization problems.

Differential calculus for functions of several variables: partial derivative, higher-order derivatives, gradient, Jacobian matrix and Hessian matrix, chain rule, application of partial derivatives in optimization problems, Lagrange multiplier method.

Integral calculus: indefinite integration, definite integration, fundamental theorem of calculus, double integral.

Optional advanced topics: improper integral and applications, directional derivative, gradient descent method.
courses.recommended_readings:
* Raymond Barnett, Michael Ziegler, Karl Bielen, Christopher Stocker: Calculus for Business, Economics, Life Sciences, and Social Sciences (any edition).
* Laurence D. Hoffmann, Gerald L. Bradley: Applied Calculus for Business, Economics, Social Sciences and Life Sciences (any edition).

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Advanced Calculus I

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT

William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT

William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT

courses.description:
This course is intended to introduce the basics of the calculus of functions of several variables. Topics include: vectors, geometry of Euclidean spaces, curves, limits, partial derivatives, differentiability, chain rule, first and second derivative test, maximum and minimum, Taylor polynomials, Lagrange multipliers, implicit function theorem.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who took MATH2018/2020/2028 or taking MATH2530 in the same term. Pre-requisite: [Option 1] MATH1010/1018 [Option 2] Grade B or above in MATH1510/1520. Check dept website for more options. Co-requisite MATH1030/1038/1050/1058/1090/1098.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students understand the basic concepts and applications of the calculus of functions of several variables, including vectors, functions of several variables, partial derivatives and their applications, and extremum problems.
courses.course_syllabus: vectors, geometry of Euclidean spaces, curves, limits, partial derivatives, differentiability, chain rule, first and second derivative test, maximum and minimum, Taylor polynomials, Lagrange multipliers, implicit function theorem.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Mathematical Analysis I
courses.description:
This course is intended to provide conceptual understanding in the theory of functions of one real variable. Topics include: real numbers, real valued functions, set notations; limits of sequences, convergence, Bolzano-Weierstrass; limits of functions, continuous functions, uniform continuity.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH2058. Pre-requisite: [Option 1] [MATH1010/1018 (or Grade B or above in MATH1510/1520)], and (MATH1050/1058/1090/1098). Check dept website for more options.
courses.learning_outcomes:
We emphasize the rigorous epsilon-delta approach to analysis, which is crucial for a solid study of analysis. After taking and passing this course, a student is expected
- to understand the axioms of the real number system (constructions such as the Dedekind cuts are not necessary),
- to know the basic properties of countable and uncountable sets (must know that real numbers and irrational numbers are uncountable) and the statement of the continuum hypothesis,
- to familiarize with the concept of limits of sequences and functions, and
- to know the concept of continuity and uniform continuity for functions on the real line as well as relevant results
courses.course_syllabus: Real numbers, real valued functions, set notations; limits of sequences, convergence, Bolzano-Weierstrass; limits of functions, continuous functions, uniform continuity.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Introduction to Real Analysis, 3rd Edition, by R.G. Bartle and D.R. Sherbert, John-Wiley and Sons, NY
- Principles of Mathematical Analysis, 3rd Edition, by W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill, International Editions
- Functions of Several Variables, 2nd Edition, by W. Fleming, Undergraduate Texts in Mathematics, Springer-Verlag, New York
- Mathematical Analysis I and II, Fudan University, Commerce Press

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Honours Mathematical Analysis I
courses.description:
This course is intended to provide conceptual understanding in the theory of functions of one or more real variables. Topics include: real numbers, real valued functions, set notations; limits of sequences (including limsup and liminf), convergence, Bolzano-Weierstrass, infinite series; limits of functions, continuous functions, uniform continuity.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students who have taken MATH2050.
Pre-requisite:[Alternative 1] Grade B- or above in each of MATH1018,1028,1098, OR in each of MATH1058 and 2018. [Alternative 2] Grade A- or above in each of MATH1010,1025,1090, OR in each of MATH1050 and 2010.
courses.learning_outcomes:
We emphasize the rigorous epsilon-delta approach to analysis, which is crucial for a solid study of analysis. After taking and passing this course, a student is expected
- to understand the axioms of the real number system (constructions such as the Dedekind cuts are not necessary),
- to know the basic properties of countable and uncountable sets (must know that real numbers and irrational numbers are uncountable) and the statement of the continuum hypothesis,
- to familiarize with the concept of limits of sequences, series and functions, and
- to know the concept of continuity and uniform continuity for functions on the real line, on higher dimensional Euclidean spaces, as well as relevant results.
courses.course_syllabus: Real numbers, real valued functions, set notations; limits of sequences (including limsup and liminf), convergence, Bolzano-Weierstrass, infinite series; limits of functions, continuous functions, uniform continuity.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Introduction to Real Analysis, 3rd Edition, by R.G. Bartle and D.R. Sherbert, John-Wiley and Sons, NY
- Principles of Mathematical Analysis, 3rd Edition, by W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill, International Editions
- Functions of Several Variables, 2nd Edition, by W. Fleming, Undergraduate Texts in Mathematics, Springer-Verlag, New York
- Mathematical Analysis I and II, Fudan University, Commerce Press

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Mathematical Analysis II
courses.description:
This is a continuation of MATH2050. Topics include: differentiability, mean-value theorem, Taylor theorem, convexity; integrability, fundamental theorem of calculus, improper integrals; power series, radius of convergence, series for elementary functions; infinite series, convergence and divergence, rearrangement; sequence and series of functions.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH2068. Pre-requisite: MATH2050/2058.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking and passing this course a student will be able
(1) to know the properties of differentiable functions and convex functions,
(2) to use Darboux sums to study Riemann integrable functions and learn the Taylor formula with remainder,
(3) to understand the fundamental theorems of calculus which relate integration to differentiation, and
(4) to know basic tests for convergence of infinite series and functions, and
(5) to know how the elementary functions including the exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric functions are rigorously defined.
In (1)-(3) he/she should master those examples and counterexamples which illustrate the applicability of various theorems.
courses.course_syllabus: Differentiability, mean-value theorem, Taylor theorem, convexity; integrability, fundamental theorem of calculus, improper integrals; power series, radius of convergence, series for elementary functions; infinite series, convergence and divergence, rearrangement; sequence and series of functions.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Introduction to Real Analysis, 3rd Edition, by R.G. Bartle and D.R. Sherbert, John-Wiley and Sons, NY
- Principles of Mathematical Analysis, 3rd Edition, by W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill, International Editions
- Functions of Several Variables, 2nd Edition, by W. Fleming, Undergraduate Texts in Mathematics, Springer-Verlag, New York
- Mathematical Analysis I and II, Fudan University, Commerce Press

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Algebraic Structures
courses.description:
This course is intended as an introduction to modern abstract algebra and the way of algebraic thinking in advanced mathematics. The course focuses on basic algebraic concepts which arise in various areas of advanced mathematics, and emphasizes on the underlying algebraic structures which are common to various concrete mathematical examples.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH2078. Pre-requisite: (MATH1030/1038 or ENGG1120/ESTR1005) and (MATH1050/1058 or 1090/1098).
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
1. define basic algebraic structures,
2. understand algebraic properties and their consequences for various algebraic structures,
3. recognize the underlying algebraic structures which are common to various concrete mathematical examples.
courses.course_syllabus: Groups including cyclic groups, permutation groups and dihedral groups, subgroups, cosets and the Theorem of Lagrange, group homomorphisms; rings including the ring of integers, polynomial rings and Boolean algebras, integral domains, fields, ring homomorphisms, subrings, ideals and quotient rings; examples of field extensions and finite fields.
courses.recommended_readings:
- J. Landin, An Introduction to Algebraic Structures, Dover
- Serge Lang, Undergraduate Algebra, Springer

courses.title: Honours Algebraic Structures
courses.description:
This course is intended as an introduction to modern abstract algebra and the way of algebraic thinking in advanced mathematics. The course focuses on basic algebraic concepts which arise in various areas of advanced mathematics, and emphasizes on the underlying algebraic structures which are common to various concrete mathematical examples.

courses.recommended_readings:

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Mathematics Laboratory II
courses.description:
This course is intended to teach numerical computing, symbolic computing, and graphical visualization through the use of mathematical and computational software so as to familiarize the students with computing skills.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Co-requisite: [Alternative 1] MATH1010/1018 and 1030/1038 and 1050/1058. [Alternative 2] MATH1010/1018 and 1025/1028 and 1030/1038 and 1090/1098.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to use MATLAB to
(a) perform direct mathematical and matrix computations
(b) develop simple algorithms
(c) perform tasks involving modeling, simulation, data analysis, and visualization
courses.course_syllabus: Topics: Mathematics operations, Arrays and Matrices, Relational and Logical Operations, Control flow, Curve fitting, Numerical Analysis, 2D and 3D Graphics, File control, Toolboxes, Symbolic Calculations

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Complex Variables with Applications
courses.description:
This course is to introduce the basic properties of complex functions and analytic functions and to illustrate the important use of these theories to other branches of mathematics and sciences. Topics include: complex numbers; limits, continuity and derivatives, Cauchy-Riemann equations, analytic functions; elementary functions; mapping by elementary functions; Contours integrals, Cauchy-Goursat theorem, Cauchy integral formula, Morera’s theorem, maximum moduli of functions, the fundamental theorem of algebra; Taylor series and Laurent’s series; residues and poles, evaluation of infinite real integrals.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: [Alternative 1] MATH2020/2028. [Alternative 2] Grade B- or above in each of MATH2018, 2058, with co-requisite MATH2020/2028. [Alternative 3] Grade A- or above in each of ENGG1120/ESTR1005, ENGG1130/ESTR1006.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
1. Define and recognize complex differentiable functions and analytic functions.
2. State the basic properties of analytic functions and major theories about these functions related to contour integration.
3. Work out the local properties at zeros or singularities of analytic functions by series or integrals.
4. Apply residue theory to evaluate real integrals.
courses.course_syllabus: Complex numbers; limits, continuity and derivatives, Cauchy-Riemann equations, analytic functions; elementary functions; mapping by elementary functions; Contours integrals, Cauchy-Goursat theorem, Cauchy integral formula, Morera’s theorem, maximum moduli of functions, the fundamental theorem of algebra; Taylor series and Laurent’s series; residues and poles, evaluation of infinite real integrals.
courses.recommended_readings:
- J. W. Brown and R. V. Churchill, Complex Variables and Applications, McGraw Hill
- E. B. Saff and A. D. Snider, Fundamental of Complex Analysis, Prentice Hall
- T. Needham, Visual Complex Analysis, Cambridge University Press

courses.title: Advanced Calculus (I) for Physical Science and Engineering

courses.description:
This course covers the most common techniques and methods of multivariable differential calculus, with an emphasis on examples of three variables. Reasoning and theory will be discussed but not in the most rigorous way. Topics include Euclidean space, Curves and its tangent frame, limits and differentiation of functions, extremum problems.
Advisory: Suitable for major in Physics, Earth System Sciences, most Engineering, and Chemistry.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH2010/2018. Pre-requisite: MATH1010/1018 or (Grade B or above in MATH1510 or 1520 or ENGG1125/ESTR1007).
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are able to deal with problems involving calculus of 3-variable functions according to the basic knowledge and principles. Methods include vector manipulation, 3-variable functions, partial derivatives and their applications, and extremum problems.
courses.course_syllabus:
Vectors and algebraic properties of Euclidean 3-space, matrices and Linear systems, linear and quadratic objects in space.
Curves, speed and velocity, tangents and normal, acceleration and curvature, curvilinear motions.
Limits of 3-variable functions, partial and directional differentiation, Chain Rules, differential and matrix approximation, multivariable differentiability; maximum and minimum, Lagrange multiplier, multivariable Taylor Formula and critical point analysis, implicit differentiation.
Methods and Applications of ODE, separable equations, first order equations, second order equations with constant coefficients.
courses.required_readings:
- Thomas, G. B., Weir, M. and Hass, J. Thomas’ Calculus: Multivariable, Chapters 12 – 14. Pearson.
- Leon, Steve., Linear Algebra with Applications, Chapters 1 – 2. Pearson.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Edwards, C. H. and Penney, D. E. Calculus: Early Transcendental. Pearson.
- Wrede, R. and Spiegel, M. Advanced Calculus: Schaum’s Outlines. McGraw Hill.
- Au, Thomas. Multivariable Differential Calculus. McGraw Hill.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Quantitative Methods for Earth and Environmental Sciences

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 401
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 401
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 401
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 401
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 401
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 401

courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the various mathematical techniques necessary for studying the Earth System and Environmental Sciences. Topics include: Foundational matrix methods, vectors and tensors as well as their linear transformations; methods for solving ordinary differential equations with examples in geochemistry, environmental chemistry and ecology; partial differentiation, line integrals and multiple integrals, and their applications in geophysics, atmospheric and ocean sciences; methods and intuition of vector calculus for use in mechanics with a focus on environmental systems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH2010/2018, 2020/2028 or 2530. Pre-requisite: MATH1010/1018 or 1510 or 1520 or ENGG1125/ESTR1007.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Vectors, Matrices and Applications
Vectors in R^2 " or " R^3, their representations in rectangular, cylindrical and spherical coordinates, System of Linear Equations and Gaussian Elimination, Matrices and its action on vectors, Orthogonal Matrix, Determinants.
2. Transcendental Functions
Logarithmic and Exponential Functions, Trigonometric and Hyperbolic Functions, their expressions in terms of one complex variable.
3. Ordinary Differential Equations – Methods and Applications
First-order Differential Equations; Second-order Differential Equations: separable equations, Equations with Constant Coefficients, The Integrating Factor Method for Homogeneous Differential Equations; Finding particular solutions for inhomogeneous Differential Equations; Examples in geochronology, geochemistry, environmental chemistry, ecology and public health
4. A Quick Study of Differential Calculus
Partial and directional derivatives, gradient and total differentials (rate of change and linear approximation), Chain Rule (including versions in terms of matrix multiplication)
5. Multiple Integration
Double Integrals in Rectangular Coordinates and Polar Coordinates; Triple Integrals in Rectangular, Cylindrical and Spherical Coordinates; Jacobian of Transformation, Surface Area and Integrals over a Curved Surface. Applications in gravity and planetary science.
6. Methods in Vector Calculus
Gradient, Divergence and Curl; Vector Operations in Various Coordinates; Physical Examples: Field Flux and Divergence Theorem, Circulation and Stokes’ Theorem, with applications in the fluid mechanics of the ocean and atmosphere, seismology, geodynamics and hydrology.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course evaluation: Tailored questionnaire to be answered by all students at the end of the course
2. Discussion with students: view and suggestions will be gathered from students
3. Reflection of teacher
courses.recommended_readings:
1. M L Boas, Mathematical Methods in the Physical Sciences, Wiley, 1983
2. W E Boyce and R C DiPrima, Elementary Differential Equations and Boundary Value Problems, New York: J. Wiley, latest ed.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Axiomatic Set Theory and Applications
courses.description:
This course is designed for both MATH and non-MATH majors who want to learn the set theoretic foundations of mathematics and its connections with other areas of thought, science and technology. The course places special emphasis on the concepts of axiomatic set-theory, computability and, time permitting, applications such as quantum computing. Familiarity with linear algebra is expected.

Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of this course, students are able to:

* Define and distinguish the usual concepts used in axiomatic set theory and its applications.
* Logically prove basic statements in axiomatic set theory and its applications.
* Appreciate the rationale and impact of axiomatic set theory and its applications to human development in science and technology.
courses.course_syllabus: First order logic, axioms and models, Zermelo-Fraenkel axioms for set-theory, Godel completeness, cardinals, ordinals and well-ordering, continuum hypothesis and the axiom of choice, Godel incompleteness, Turing machines, Halting problem, P vs NP, and time permitting the basics of quantum computation.
courses.recommended_readings:
* Quantum Computing Since Democritus, Aaronson
* Introduction to Set Theory, Hrbacek and Jech

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Abstract Algebra
courses.description:
This course is an introduction to modern abstract algebra, focusing on groups and rings. It is a continuation of MATH2070/2078. Students are expected to have knowledge in MATH2070/2078, or equivalent.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: [Alternative 1] MATH2070/2078. [Alternative 2] Grade A- or above in MATH2040/2048, with co-requisite MATH2070/2078.
courses.course_syllabus:
Group theory: normal subgroups, quotient groups, direct products, structure of finitely generated abelian groups, group action, Cayley's theorem, Sylow theorems.
Ring theory: prime and maximal ideals, polynomial rings, factorization in integral domains, principal ideal domains, unique factorization domains.
courses.recommended_readings:
A First Course in Abstract Algebra, by J. B. Fraleigh
Algebra, by M. Artin
Algebra, by T. W. Hungerford
Abstract Algebra, by D. S. Dummit and R. M. Foote

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Fields and Galois Theory
courses.description:
This course is an introduction to the theory of field extensions and Galois theory. It is one of the continuations of MATH3030 (the other being MATH4080). Students are expected to have knowledge in MATH2070/2078 and MATH3030, or equivalent.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MATH3030.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include: field extensions, algebraic extensions, algebraic closures, geometric constructions, finite fields, splitting fields, separable and inseparable extensions, Galois extensions, Galois correspondences, cyclotomic extensions, solvability by radicals, etc.
courses.recommended_readings:
A First Course in Abstract Algebra, by J. B. Fraleigh
Algebra, by M. Artin
Algebra, by T. W. Hungerford
Abstract Algebra, by D. S. Dummit and R. M. Foote

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Mathematical Analysis III

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804

courses.description:
This course is a continuation of MATH2060. It provides rigorous treatment on further topics in mathematical analysis. This course is essential for studying advanced mathematics, pure or applied, to the level beyond undergraduate. Topics include: Fourier series, pointwise and uniform convergence of Fourier series, $L^2$-completeness of Fourier series. Parseval's identity; metric spaces, open sets and continuity, completion of a metric space, contraction mapping principle; the space of continuous functions, Weierstrass approximation theorem, Stone-Weierstrass theorem, Baire category theorem, continuous but nowhere differentiable functions, equicontinuity and Ascoli's theorem; implicit and inverse function theorems, functional dependence and independence; fundamental existence and uniqueness theorem for differential equations, the continuous dependence of the solution on initial time and values.

Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MATH2060 or MATH2068
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, a student will be able to

1. how to expand a function into a Fourier series and under what conditions the Fourier series converges to the function,

2. describe to describe limit and continuity in terms of open sets in a metric space,

3. use the contraction principle to solve some equations,

4. apply the fundamental results such as Stone-Weierstrass theorem, Baire category theorem and Ascoli's theorem in his/her further studies in analysis,

5. understand the proofs of the implicit and inverse function theorem and many of their applications, and

6. the details in the proof of the fundamental existence and uniqueness of differential equations, a theorem stated in MATH3270.
courses.course_syllabus: Fourier series, pointwise and uniform convergence of Fourier series, $L^2$-completeness of Fourier series. Parseval's identity; metric spaces, open sets and continuity, completion of a metric space, contraction mapping principle, existence and uniqueness of the fundamental theorem of differential equations; the space of continuous functions, Weierstrass approximation theorem, Stone-Weierstrass theorem, Baire category theorem, continuous but nowhere differentiable functions, equicontinuity and Ascoli's theorem; Implicit and inverse function theorems, functional dependence and independence; the continuous dependence of the solution on initial time and values.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Fourier Series, G P Tolstov, Dover Publication, New York.

- Topology, 2nd ed., J R Munkres, Prentice Hill, New Jersey.

- Foundation of Modern Analysis, J. Dieudonne, Academic Press, New York.

courses.title: Introduction to Topology
courses.description:
Topological Space: open set, closed set, compact set, limit pint, Heine-Borel Theorem, continuous map, homeomorphism, connectedness, metric space, group action on a topological space and quotient topology. Fundamental Group: loop, space of loops, homotopy, calculation of fundamental groups of some spaces, path lifting lemma, homotopy lifting lemma, fundamental groups of quotient spaces of free discrete group actions.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite: 
[Alternative 1] MATH3060
[Alternative 2] Grade B- or above in both MATH2050/2058 and MATH2060/2068.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students understand the concepts listed in the course content.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topological Space: open set, closed set, compact set, limit pint, Heine-Borel Theorem, continuous map, homeomorphism, connectedness, metric space, group action on a topological space, quotient topology.
Fundamental Group: loop, space of loop, homotopy, calculation of fundamental groups of some spaces, path lifting lemma, homotopy lifting lemma, fundamental groups of quotient spaces of free discrete group actions.

- Armstrong, Basic Topology, Springer
- Munkres, Topology, 2nd Edition, Pearson

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Number Theory
courses.description:
This course is intended to introduce the students to the intriguing structure of integers. Topics are usually selected from: divisibility theory of the integers, primes, congruence, Fermat's little theorem, some arithmetic functions, primitive roots and indices. Students are expected to have knowledge in MATH2070/2078, or equivalent.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Students learn basic concepts and results about divisibility of integers, including greatest common divisor, Euclid’s algorithm, fundamental theorem of arithmetic, properties of primes.
- Students learn some typical arithmetic functions and learn the Mobius inversion formulae, learn some properties of the Riemann zeta-function.
- Students learn some fundamental results about congruence, such as Chinese remainder theorem, Fermat, Euler, Lagrange’s theorems; and learn how to solve linear congruence equations; learn the concepts and properties of primitive roots and indices.
- Students learn some concepts and results about quadratic residues, such as Legendre symbol, Jacobi’s symbol and law of quadratic reciprocity; learn how to solve quadratic congruence equations.
- Students learn some elementary results on quadratic forms: the representations of integers by binary forms, in particular the representation of integers as the sum of squares.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics are usually selected from: divisibility theory of the integers, primes, congruence, Fermat’s little theorem, some arithmetic functions, primitive roots and indices.
courses.recommended_readings:
Main Reference:
- An introduction to the theory of numbers, by Ivan Niven and Herbert S. Zuckerman, New York, Wiley
Other References:
- Elementary number theory, by M. Burton, Dubuque, Iowa, Wm. C. Brown Publishers
- An introduction to the theory of numbers, by G.H. Hardy and E.M. Wright, Oxford, Claredon Press
- Elementary number theory and its application, by Kenneth H. Rosen, Reading, Mass., Addison-Wesley

courses.description: This course is an introduction to Fourier series and Fourier transform. Topics include: Orthogonal families of functions, mean-square convergence of Fourier series and completeness, pointwise convergence of Fourier series, Gibbs's phenomenon; Fourier transform and its inversion, Plancherel formula. Further topics will be selected from: The isoperimetric inequality, Poisson summation formula Heisenberg uncertainty principle, and the notion of a wavelet.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MATH2060/2068.
courses.learning_outcomes:
We introduce the students to the some basic ingredients of Fourier analysis and get a flavor of the modern theoretical mathematics, and enable them to produce rigorous mathematical proofs based on abstract theory on their own. Upon completion of the course, students should be able to
- learn the basics of orthogonal families of functions, mean-square convergence of Fourier series and completeness, pointwise convergence of Fourier series;
- learn the basics of Fourier transform and its inversion, Plancherel formula, Poisson summation formula and Heisenberg uncertainty principle,
- apply basic results and techniques to solve problems in the theory and other related subjects.
- prepare for further studies on related topics in analysis.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include: Orthogonal families of functions, mean-square convergence of Fourier series and completeness, pointwise convergence of Fourier series, Gibbs's phenomenon; Fourier transform and its inversion, Plancherel formula. Further topics will be selected from: The isoperimetric inequality, Poisson summation formula Heisenberg uncertainty principle, and the notion of a wavelet.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Operations Research

meetings.location: Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall2

courses.description:
Operations Research (OR) refers to the science of decision making. It uses various problem-solving techniques and methods to analyse system behavior and improve decision-making and efficiency by arriving at optimal or near optimal solutions to complex decision problems. This course provides a fundamental account of the basic results and techniques of Linear Programming (LP), network optimization and integer programming in Operations Research. There is an equal emphasis on all three aspects of theory, algorithms as well as applications, which provides essential optimization concept and background for more advanced studies in Operations Research. Students taking this course are expected to have basic knowledge in linear algebra. They are also expected to have basic programming skills in some programming language (such as MATLAB, C++, Python).
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MATH1030/1038 or ENGG1120/ESTR1005.
courses.course_syllabus: A wide array topics will be covered, including linear programming and simplex method, as well as related analytical topics. It will also introduce other types of mathematical models, including transportation problems, network problems, integer programming, and so on.
courses.required_readings: None. The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.
courses.recommended_readings:
Operations Research: An Introduction, by H.F. Taha
Introduction to Operations Research, by F.S. Hillier and G.J. Lieberman
Linear and Nonlinear Programming, by D.G. Luenberger and Y.Y. Ye
Introduction to Linear Optimization, by D. Bertsimas and J.N. Tsitsiklis

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Numerical Analysis
courses.description:
Floating-point numbers and roundoff errors, absolute and relative errors, stable and unstable computations, solutions of nonlinear equations, linear systems, interpolation, numerical differentiation, and numerical integration. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and linear algebra. They are also expected to have basic programming skills in some programming language (such as MATLAB, C++, Python).
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to understand the fundamental concepts involved in numerical analysis, and learn some basic approaches and techniques in solving linear and nonlinear systems, constructing interpolations and do numerical differntiation and integration. The basic learning outcomes include:

- Students understand the basic concepts in scientific computings, including fixed-point numbers, floating-point numbers, single and double precision, overflow and underflow, roundoff errors, absolute and relative errors, stable and unstable computations.

- Students learn some basic knowledge in floating-point arithmetic and know how to use the backward error analysis to estimate possible errors generated in numerical computings.

- Students learn some basic concepts in solving nonlinear equations of one variable: iterative methods, rate of convergence, local and global convergence; learn some classical methods for solving nonlinear equations of one variable: bisection methods, Newton's method, quasi-Newton's method and fixed-point iteration, and learn how to analyse convergence of these method.

- Students learn some basic methods for solving linear system of equations: Cholesky factorization, LU and LDU factorization, forward- and backward-substitutions for traingular systems, Gaussian elimination.

- Students learn sensitivity analysis of the solutions of linear systems with respect to some errors in their coefficient matrices or in their right-hand sides, and understand condition numbers and their importance.

- Students learn three polynomial interpolations, Newton form of interpolations, Lagrange and spline interpolations, and learn how to estimate the interpolation errors.

- Students learn some popular numerical integrations: trapezoidal and composite trapezoidal rules, Simpson and composite Simpson rules, Newton-Cotes quadrature rule, Gaussian quadrature rules, and learn how to estimate the errors of quadrature rules.

- Students learn some basic numerical differentiation techniques: forward differences, backward differences, central differences, and understand how to estimate the errors of these difference schemes.
courses.course_syllabus: Floating-point numbers and roundoff errors, absolute and relative errors, stable and unstable computations, solutions of nonlinear equations, linear systems, interpolation, numerical differentiation, numerical integration.
courses.recommended_readings:
Main Reference:

- D. Kincaid & W. Cheney, Numerical Analysis: Mathematics of Scientific Computing, Brooks/Cole Publishing Co., New York

- G.W. Stewart, Afternotes on Numerical Analysis, SIAM

Other References:

- R. L. Burden and J. D. Faires, Numerical Analysis, Brooks/Cole-Thomson Learning

- C.F. Gerald and P.O. Wheatley, Applied Numerical Analysis, Person Addison Wesley

- G.H. Golub and C.F. van Loan, Matrix computations, Johns Hopkins University Press, MD

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Numerical Methods for Differential Equations

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803

courses.description:
Numerical solution of ordinary differential equations, numerical solution of partial differential equations. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and linear algebra. They are also expected to have basic programming skills in some programming language (such as MATLAB, C++, Python).
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to understand some fundamental concepts involved in numerical methods for differential equations, and learn some basic approaches and techniques in solving ordinary and partial differential equations. The basic learning outcomes include:

- Students understand the importance of differential equations in modeling real-world phenomena and understand the meanings and importance of numerical methods in solving general ordinary and partial differential equations.

- Students learn some basic mathematical method of verifying the well-posedness of a ordinary differential equation (ODE).

- For a given first order ODE, students learn how to construct Taylor-series methods and Runge-Kutta methods with orders up to four.

- Students learn some basic approaches to constructing multistep methods: the quadrature rule approach, test function approach by polynomials, Adams-Bashforth and Adams-Mouton methods. And learn how to solve ODEs using multistep methods and predictor-corrector methods.

- Students learn how to compute the orders of multistep methods, and how to analyse consistency, stability and convergence of multistep methods and understand the relationship between these three concepts.

- Students learn how to convert a higher order ODE into a system of first order ODEs and how to construct Taylor-series methods and Runge-Kutta methods for the resulting ODE system.

- Students learn some important numerical methods for solving stiff ODEs, and understand the importance of A-stability, absolute stability and regions of absolute stability.

- Students learn how to use the shooting method to transform a two-point boundary value problem into an initial value problem.

- Students learn some basic finite difference schemes and collocation methods to solve two-point boundary value problems.

- Students learn some basic finite difference schemes to solve the one- and two-dimensional parabolic equations, and know how to analyse the consistency, stability and convergence of a finite difference scheme.

- Students learn some simple finite element methods to solve the one- and two-dimensional parabolic equations.
courses.course_syllabus: Numerical solution of ordinary differential equations, numerical solution of partial differential equations.
courses.recommended_readings:
Main Reference:

- D. Kincaid and W. Cheney, Numerical Analysis: Mathematics of Scientific Computing, Brooks/Cole Publishing Co.

- Quarteroni and A. Valli, Numerical Mathematics, Springer-verlag

Other References:

- U. Ascher, R. Mattheij and R. Russell, Numerical solution of boundary value problems for ordinary differential equations, SIAM, Philadelphia

- K. Atkinson, An Introduction to Numerical Analysis. Wiley, New York

- C. Gerald and C. Wheatley, Applied Numerical analysis, Addison-Wesley Pub. Co.

- Jianwei Hu and Huai-ming Tang, Numerical methods for differential equations (in Chinese), Science Press

- Likang Li, Conghua yu et al., Numerical methods for differential equations (in Chinese), Fudan University Press

- Ronghua Li and Guochen Feng, Numerical Solutions of Partial Differential Equations, Advanced Education Press (in Chinese)

- Quarteroni and A. Valli, Numerical approximation of partial differential equations, Springer-verlag

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Discrete Mathematics
courses.description:
This is an introductory course of discrete mathematics. Topics will be chosen from: set theory and logic, algorithms, number theory, information theory, algebraic structures, combinatorics, probability, calculus and finite difference, discrete and computational geometry, graph theory, automata theory, game theory.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students should:

1. Understand the basics in different areas of discrete mathematics

2. Solve application problem by using appropriate mathematical tools

3. Encompass an appreciation of the interplay between theory and practice
courses.course_syllabus: Topics will be chosen from: set theory and logic, algorithms, number theory, information theory, algebraic structures, combinatorics, probability, calculus and finite difference, discrete and computational geometry, graph theory, automata theory, game theory.

courses.title: Graph Theory
courses.description:
Definitions and applications of graphs and digraphs, Eulerian graphs, Hamiltonian graphs, path algorithm, connectivity, trees, planarity and coloring graphs.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to learn and appreciate the rigorous and theoretical foundations as well as to recognize important applications of Graph Theory. The ability to formulate a problem and develop a mathematical treatment is also enhanced.
courses.course_syllabus: Definitions and applications of graphs and digraphs, Eulerian graphs, Hamiltonian graphs, path algorithm, connectivity, trees, planarity and coloring graphs.
