courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
courses.description:
Ordinary differential equations arise from quantitative description of natural and social phenomena. Topics are: method of explicit solution, linear equations and systems, series solutions, Sturm-Liouville boundary value problems, dynamical systems and stability, applications to mechanics, electrical networks and population of species.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MATH1030/1038 or ENGG1120/ESTR1005.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking and passing this course, a student should be able
- to solve first or second order ODE’s by elementary methods such as change of variables and power series expansion,
- to understand the structure theory of linear systems of equations,
- on the theoretical side, to master the proof of the fundamental theorem on existence and uniqueness of solution to a general ODE, and
- to understand the basic concept of stability of a solution including some examples arising from mathematical biology.
- to know the set-up of the Sturm-Liouville boundary value problems.
courses.course_syllabus: Ordinary differential equations arise from quantitative description of natural and social phenomena. Topics are: methods of explicit solution, linear equations and systems, series solutions, Sturm-Liouville boundary value problems, dynamical systems and stability, applications to mechanics, electrical networks and population of species.
courses.recommended_readings:
- W. E. Boyce, R. C. DiPrima, Elementary Differential Equations and Boundary Value Problems, Wiley
- C. H. Edwards, D. E. Penney, Elementary Differential Equations with Applications, Pearson College Div
- R. K. Nagle, E. B. Saff, A. D. Snider, Fundamentals of Differential Equations and Boundary Value Problems, Pearson Addison-Wesley
- E. A. Coddington, N. Levinson, Theory of ordinary differential equations, McGraw-Hill

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Introductory Probability
courses.description:
Axioms of probability, conditional probability, independence, discrete random variables, continuous random variables, mean, variance and covariance, moment generating function, Poisson distributions, normal distributions, central limit theorem, law of large numbers, random walks, transition probabilities and Markov chains. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MIEG2440/ESTR2362.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students learn the basic concepts of probability. They include: conditional probability, random variables, distributions, expectation and Limit theorems. Also students learn their applications in physical science and engineering.
courses.course_syllabus: Axioms of probability, conditional probability, independence, discrete random variables, continuous random variables, mean, variance and covariance, moment generating function, Poisson distributions, normal distributions, central limit theorem, law of large numbers, random walks, transition probabilities and Markov chains.
courses.recommended_readings: - S. Ghahramani, Fundamentals of Probability, Prentice Hall

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Mathematical Modeling
courses.description:
This course introduces the concept of mathematical modeling. Topics include: different modeling techniques such as modeling with differential equations and modeling with linear programming, forecasting; economic models such as Markov models, network models and financial models such as input-output models and scheduling models.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to learn some basic techniques and mathematical tools to set up a mathematical model for a given real-world problem, and to be able to do simulations using a model and to know how to improve a model. The basic learning outcomes include:

- Students understand practical meanings and importance of mathematical modeling in various applications.

- For a given real-world process, students learn how to identify the problem to be modeled by selecting only those most important and relevant factors.

- For a given real-world process, students understand the basic procedures to set up a mathematical model.

- Students learn modeling with discrete dynamical systems and difference equations to predict the future based on what is known at the present and the observed changes.

- Students understand the concepts of long-time behaviors of solutions to a discrete dynamical system and their relation to equilibrium values of the system, and understand how to identify stability and instability of an equilibrium value.

- Students learn how to analyses the sensitivity of a model to its initial conditions and model parameters.

- For a given set of observed data, students learn how to formulate a model using the Chebyshev approximation criterion, the criterion of minimizing the sum of absolute deviations and the least-squares criterion. And understand the relations between the three criteria and learn some basic solution techniques to solve the resulting model systems.

- For a given real-world process, students learn how to find an appropriate model after trying various types of model functions.

- Students understand the advantages and disadvantages of polynomial models, and understand the smoothing effects by low-order polynomials.

- Students learn how to simulate deterministic behaviors by Monte Carlo algorithms and probabilistic behaviors by probability models.

- Students learn how to set up a discrete optimization model and solve linear programming models by simplex method.

- Students learn modeling with differential equations, and know how to plot phase lines and sketch solution curves based on equilibrium solutions and signs of first and second derivatives.

- Students learn how to apply the Lagrange multiplier method to solve constrained optimization problems.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include: different modeling techniques such as modeling with differential equations and modeling with linear programming, forecasting; economic models such as Markov models, network models and financial models such as input-output models and scheduling models.
courses.recommended_readings:
Main References:

- F. Giordano, M. Weir and W. Fox, A First Course in Mathematical Modeling, Brooks/Cole Publishing Company, third edition

Other References:

- W.J. Meyer, Concepts of mathematical modeling, McGraw-Hill Book Company

- R.Haberman, Mathematical Models, SIAM, Philadelphia

- G. Lei, Mathematical Modeling, Peking University Press

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Computational and Applied Mathematics
courses.description:
This course introduces the general solution methods used in computational and applied mathematics. The central topics are differential equations and matrix equations. Methods include Fourier series, orthogonal expansion, conformal mapping, Fourier integrals, complex integration, LU decomposition, Newton method, semi-direct and iterative methods, the finite element methods and fast Fourier transform. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and linear algebra.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to learn some general mathematical methods which are frequently used in computational and applied mathematics, as well as in the physics and engineering applications. The basic learning outcomes include:

- Students learn some basic techniques of solving two-point elliptic boundary value problems (BVPs), and understand how to formulate a BVP into an equivalent minimization problem and an equivalent variational problem.

- Students learn some basic vector calculus in Euclidiean space, including gradient, divergence and vorticity operations, and know how to express a differential equation in the rectangular coordinate system, cylindrical coordinate system and spherical coordinate system.

- Students learn how to compute a real and complex Fourier series for a given periodic function, and understand the relation between the real and complex Fourier series.

- Students learn how to solve some standard differential equations in certain nice domains, like Laplace equation in a unit disk, by using the Fourier series.

- Students learn how to construct a series of orthonormal polynomial functions by Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization process.

- Students learn how to find the Fourier and inverse Fourier transforms, as well as the discrete Fourier transform for a given function.

- Students learn the LU factorization for a given matrix and its relation with Gaussian elimination.

- Students learn how to solve nonlinear systems of equations by Newton's method, and how to solve linear systems of equations by Jacobi, Gauss-Seidal and successive overrelaxation methods, and understand why these methods work or do not work for some linear or nonlinear systems.

- Students learn how to find the eigenvalues of a matrix by QR factorization and understand the mathematics behind.

- Students learn the fast Fourier transform and its applications.

- Students learn how to solve a two-point boundary value problem by a simple finite element method.
courses.course_syllabus: This course introduces the general solution methods used in computational and applied mathematics. The central topics are differential equations and matrix equations. Methods include Fourier series, orthogonal expansion, conformal mapping, Fourier integrals, complex integration, LU decomposition, Newton method, semi-direct and iterative methods, the finite element methods and fast Fourier transform. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and linear algebra.
courses.recommended_readings:
Main References:

- Gilbert Strang, Introduction to Applied Mathematics, Wellesley-Cambridge Press

Other References:

- Curtis F. Gerald and Patrick O. Wheatley, Applied Numerical Analysis, Addison-Wesley

- Gene Golub and Charles Van Loan, Matrix computations, Johns Hopkins University Press

- J. David Logan, Applied mathematics, Wiley

- Gilbert Strang, Linear algebra and its applications, second edition, Academic Press, New York

- Gilbert Strang and George Fix, An analysis of the finite element method, Englewood Cliffs, N.J., Prentice Hall

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Foundation of Data Analytics
courses.description:
This course gives an introduction to computational data analytics, with emphasis on its mathematical foundations. The goal is to carefully develop and explore mathematical theories and methods that make up the backbone of modern mathematical data sciences, such as knowledge discovery in databases, machine learning, and mathematical artificial intelligence. Topics include mathematical foundations of probability, linear approximation and its polynomial and high dimensional extensions, proper orthogonal decomposition methods, optimization, theories of nonlinear neural network and approximations. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge of basic linear algebra. They are also expected to have basic programming skills in some programming language (such as MATLAB, C++, Python).
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Learning outcomes:
On completion of this course, students will be able to:
• Understand in-depth the various topics in modern data analysis and the technical difficulties in solving them
• Acquire knowledge about the foundation of computational data analytics
• Learn how to use various mathematical models to extract important information from big data
• Systematically evaluate the performance of different models to solve various data analysis problems
• Understand the importance of computational data analytics for real-world problems
courses.course_syllabus: Cover various topics related to computational data analytics, including mathematical foundations of probability, linear approximation and its polynomial and high dimensional extensions, proper orthogonal decomposition methods, optimization, theories of nonlinear neural network and approximations.
courses.required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Big Data Computing
courses.description:
This course provides students with practical experience in using mathematical techniques for big data computing, numerical optimization and simulations of practical mathematical models through various programming and software implementation. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in mathematical foundation of data analytics.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: AIST1110 or CSCI 1020 or CSCI1110 or CSCI1120 or CSCI1130 or CSCI1510 or CSCI1520 or CSCI1530 or CSCI1540 or ESTR1100 or ESTR1102 or IERG1080 or MATH2221.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of this course, students will be able to:
• Acquire practical experiences in big data computing
• Use of common software packages for big data computing
• Learn how to use mathematical machine learning algorithms to solve problems
• Design solution strategies using sophisticated mathematical modelling and computational techniques for real life applications
courses.course_syllabus: Cover mathematical techniques for big data computing, numerical optimization and simulations of practical mathematical models through various programming and software implementation.
courses.required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.

courses.title: Mathematics of Machine Learning

courses.description: This course presents the fundamental mathematical theory for modern machine learning techniques, including empirical risk minimization (error decomposition, Rademacher complexity, covering number), optimization method (gradient descent and stochastic gradient descent), kernel methods, and deep neural networks (approximation theory and over-parameterization). Students are expected to have knowledge in MATH2040/2048, MATH2050/2058 and MATH2060/2068, or equivalent. Familiarity with basic concepts about probability theory (e.g., knowledge in MATH3280), and basic programming skills in some programming language (such as MATLAB, C++, Python) will be helpful though not compulsory.
courses.learning_outcomes: On completion of this course, students are able to understand some classical analysis techniques in statistical learning theory, and to familiarize the skills in learning theory.
courses.course_syllabus: Linear regression, empirical risk optimization, gradient type optimization algorithms, kernel methods and deep neural networks
courses.required_readings: Chosen by instructor from the Recommended Readings below.
courses.recommended_readings:
- F. Bach, Learning Theory from First Principles, 2023
- P. L Bartlett, A. Montanari, A. Rakhlin. Deep learning: a statistical viewpoint. Acta Numerica, 2021
- S. Shalev-Shwartz, S Ben-David, Understanding Machine Learning, CUP, 2014

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Mathematical Imaging
courses.description:
This course gives an introduction on mathematical models and techniques for various image processing tasks. A wide array of topics will be covered, including image restoration (denoising, deblurring), image decomposition, image segmentation, image registration, feature detection, multi-scale image analysis, morphology and so on. Students will become familiar with essential mathematical techniques for imaging tasks, such as image processing in the spatial domain (using gradient, Laplacian, convolution) and frequency domain (using Fourier / wavelet transform). Variational models and PDE-based techniques will also be discussed.
Students are expected to have basic knowledge in calculus and linear algebra. Some basic programming skills, such as Matlab, C++ or other programming languages, are also expected for programming exercises. Some background in numerical analysis, Fourier analysis and partial differential equations will be helpful, although the necessary concepts will be discussed as they are used.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MATH1030/1038 and MATH2010/2018.
courses.course_syllabus: A wide array topics will be covered, including image restoration (denoising, deblurring), image decomposition, image segmentation, image registration, feature detection, multi-scale image analysis, morphology and so on.
courses.required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Digital Image Processing (3rd edition) by Gonzales & Woods
- Image Processing and Analysis: Variational, PDE, Wavelet, and Stochastic Methods by Tony F. Chan, Jianhong (Jackie) Shen

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Functional Analysis
courses.description:
Metric spaces, fixed point theorems, Banach spaces, Hilbert spaces, continuous linear operator, the Hahn-Banach extension theorem, the uniform boundedness principle and the open mapping theorem, and applications of the above topics. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis and linear algebra.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite: 
[Alternative 1] MATH3060
[Alternative 2] Grade B- or above in both MATH2050/2058 and MATH2060/2068.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This is an advanced undergraduate course. We expect students to understand how linear algebra and analysis can be put together to become one of the most important fields of mathematics; we also emphasize the generality and depth of this treatment as a useful tool in many other disciplines and for graduate study.
- Students are expected to know the distance concept in metric spaces, and point set topology such as open sets and close sets, convergence, Cauchy sequences, completion, continuity.
- Students learn the concept of norm linear spaces, Banach spaces, compactness of finite dimensional spaces, bounded linear operators, functionals and dual spaces.
- Students learn inner product spaces, Hilbert spaces, orthogonality and direct sums. These concepts will be used in Fourier series and other classical orthogonal series.
- Students learn the Reiesz representation theorem on Hilbert space and use it to define the adjoint operators. An elementary theory on self-adjoint operator will be developed.
- Students learn the fundamental theorems for normed linear spaces: the Hahn-Banach theorem and its applications to the Reiesz representation theorem on continuous function space, the uniform boundedness principle, the open mapping theorem. The concept of strong and weak convergence will be introduced.
- Students learn how to solve some standard differential equations in certain nice domains, like Laplace equation in a unit disk, by using the Fourier series.
- Students learn how to construct a series of orthonormal polynomial functions by Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization process.
- Students learn how to find the Fourier and inverse Fourier transforms, as well as the discrete Fourier transform for a given function.
- Students learn the LU factorization for a given matrix and its relation with Gaussian elimination.
- Students learn how to solve nonlinear systems of equations by Newton's method, and how to solve linear systems of equations by Jacobi, Gauss-Seidal and successive overrelaxation methods, and understand why these methods work or do not work for some linear or nonlinear systems.
- Students learn how to find the eigenvalues of a matrix by QR factorization and understand the mathematics behind.
- Students learn the fast Fourier transform and its applications.
- Students learn how to solve a two-point boundary value problem by a simple finite element method.
courses.course_syllabus: Metric spaces, fixed point theorems, Banach spaces, Hilbert spaces, continuous linear operator, the Hahn-Banach extension theorem, the uniform boundedness principle and the open mapping theorem, and applications of the above topics. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis and linear algebra.
courses.recommended_readings:
Main References:
- Introduction to Functional Analysis with Applications, E. Kreysgiz, Wiley
Other References:
- Introduction to Topology and Modern Analysis, G.F. Simons, McGraw-Hill
- Real Analysis, H. Royden, Macmillian
- Real and Complex Analysis, W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill
- Functional Analysis, W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Calculus of Variations
courses.description:
This course is intended to provide a basic theory of calculus of variations. Topics are usually selected from: necessary condition for extremum, Euler equation, fixed end point problem for unknown functions involving higher-order derivatives, natural boundary condition and transversality, Weierstrass-Erdman corner conditions, and sufficient conditions. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Students learn classical examples of variational problems such as the brachistochrone and geodesic.
- Students learn the basic concepts in theory of calculus of variations such as functional in one or several dimensions, relative maximum, relative minimum, and stationary point.
- Students learn the method of first variation to find Euler-Lagrange equation in various boundary conditions.
- Students learn the constraint problems and method of Lagrange multipliers.
- Students learn the second variation, Legendre’s condition and Jacobi’s condition.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics are usually selected from: necessary condition for extremum, Euler equation, fixed end point problem for unknown functions involving higher-order derivatives, natural boundary condition and transversality, Weierstrass-Erdman corner conditions, and sufficient conditions.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Mark Kot, A First Course in Calculus of Variations, AMS, 2014
- Bruce van Brunt, The Calculus of Variations, Universitext, Springer

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Differential Geometry
courses.description:
This course covers basic theory on curves, and surfaces in the Euclidean three space. Topics include: regular curves, Frenet formulas, local theory of curves, global properties of curves such as isoperimetric inequality, regular surfaces, 1st and 2nd fundamental form, Gaussian curvature and mean curvature, Gauss map, special surfaces such as ruled surfaces, surfaces of revolution, minimal surfaces, intrinsic geometry: geodesic, and Gauss-Bonnet Theorem. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus, linear algebra, and elementary differential equations.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH4033.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Students learn ways to describe curves and surfaces in space, by equations and parametrizations.

- Students learn the differential approach to regular geometric objects, using moving frames and searching for complete local invariants. In particular, they learn the Frenet frame, curvature and torsion of regular space curves.

- Students use integration techniques to study some global theorems on plane curves and methods of ordinary differential equations to obtain curves with prescribed curvature and torsion.

- Students learn the formulation of regular surfaces in 3 dimensions, their orientability, differentiable structure and metric structure.

- Students learn the Gauss map and its many important consequences.

- Students learn computations of various curvatures through examples and special surfaces.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include: regular curves, Frenet formulas, local theory of curves, global properties of curves such as isoperimetric inequality, regular surfaces, 1st and 2nd fundamental form, Gaussian curvature and mean curvature, Gauss map, special surfaces such as ruled surfaces, surfaces of revolution, minimal surfaces, intrinsic geometry: geodesics and Gauss-Bonnet Theorem.
courses.recommended_readings:
References:

- M.P. do Carmo, Differential Geometry of Curves and Surfaces, Prentice Hall

- B. O’Neill, Elementary Differential Geometry, Academic Press

- J.J. Stoker, Differential Geometry, Wiley

- J. Opera, Differential Geometry and Its Applications, 2nd Edition, Pearson

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Real Analysis
courses.description:
This is an introductory course on the Lebesgue integration theory on real line. Topics include: measurable sets, measurable functions, Lebesgue integral, Fatou's lemma, monotone convergence theorem, Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem and differentiation. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MATH2050/2058.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Students learn the basic properties of measurable sets and measurable functions on the real line.

- Students learn the introduction of Lebesgue integration and its basic properties.

- Students learn the fundamental convergence theorems including Fatou's lemma, monotone convergence theorem, Lebesgue dominate convergence theorem and results in connection with differentiation.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include: measurable sets, measurable functions, Lebesgue integral, Fatou’s lemma, monotone convergence theorem, Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem and differentiation. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis.
courses.recommended_readings:
- H.L. Royden, Real Analysis (3rd Ed), Prentice Hall

- W. Rudin, Real and Complex Analysis, McGraw Hill

- E. Hewitt and K. Stromberg, Real and Abstract Analysis, Springer-Verlag

- K. R. Davidson and A. Donsig, Real Analysis with Real Applications, Prentice Hall

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Complex Analysis
courses.description:
This course is designed for students who are intending to acquire advanced theoretical understanding about analytic functions, which is typically needed for further studies. The course emphasizes the rigorous treatment of the analysis of complex functions. Students are expected to have sophisticated mathematics background and superb theoretical knowledge in multivariable calculus. Major topics include entire functions of infinite series and infinite products, normal families, theory of conformal mappings. Details are given in course syllabus.

Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MATH2230 and MATH3060.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will be able to state and prove important theorems about analytic functions, including sequence or series of functions, local and global theories.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Quick review of functions of one complex variable.
2. Jensen’s formula, infinite products, Hadamard’s Theorem, Gamma and Zeta functions.
3. Normal families, Arzela-Ascoli’s Theorem.
4. Conformal mappings, Schwarz lemma, Riemann Mapping Theorem, mappings of polygons.
5. Optional topics selected from
a. Dirichlet problems, harmonic and subharmonic functions
b. Famous examples of elliptic functions
c. Analytic continuation and monodromy
d. Basic Riemann surfaces
courses.recommended_readings:
• Ellias Stein and Rami Shakarchi: Complex Analysis. Princeton University Press.
• Lars V. Ahlfors: Complex Analysis. McGraw Hill.
• Tristan Needham: Visual Complex Analysis. Oxford University Press.
• Walter Rudin: Real and Complex Analysis. McGraw Hill.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Modules and Representation Theory
courses.description:
This course is an introduction to modules over rings, as well as the representation theory of finite groups. It is one of the continuations of MATH3030 (the other being MATH3040). Students are expected to have knowledge in MATH2070/2078 and MATH3030, or equivalent.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MATH3030.
courses.course_syllabus: Modules are to rings as vector spaces to fields, and they form a model for linear structures that occur all over mathematics. Topics include basic structural theory of modules, modules over principal ideal domains, group representations and group rings, Maschke's theorem, character theory, constructions of representations, etc.
courses.recommended_readings:
Algebra, by M. Artin
Algebra, by S. Lang
Abstract Algebra, by D. S. Dummit and R. M. Foote
Representation Theory of Finite Groups, by B. Sternberg

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Financial Mathematics
courses.description:
Topics of this course will include: Basic option theory, forward and futures contracts, model of asset price, Ito's Lemma, asset price random walk, Black-Scholes model, free boundary problems of options, constrained matrix problems and the projected SOR method, discrete random walk model and the binomial methods. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in probability and differential equations.

In this course, the students are expected to learn

- European Options

- American Options

- Interest Rates

- Put-Call Parity

- Trading Strategies

- Geometric Brownian Motions

- Ito's Lemma

- Black-Scholes Equations

- Extension of Black-Scholes Model

- Binomial Method

- Finite Difference Methods
courses.course_syllabus: Topics of this course will include: Basic option theory, forward and futures contracts, model of asset price, Ito’s Lemma, asset price random walk, Black-Scholes model, free boundary problems of options, constrained matrix problems and the projected SOR method, discrete random walk model and the binomial methods.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Partial Differential Equations
courses.description:
This is an introduction to the classical theory of partial differential equations. Topics are usually selected from: First-order equations, types of second-order equations, well-posedness of the wave and the heat equations, boundary value problems for the Laplace and Poisson equations, separation of variables. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
In general, the goal is to let the student understand the basic properties of the three principal types- hyperbolic, elliptic and parabolic equations. After taking and passing this course, a student is expected

- to distinguish the types of the equations and use change of variables to simplify them,

- to solve well-posed problems by the method of separation of variables. (In particular, he/she should be able to use this method to solve the mixed problems including one-dimensional wave and heat equations as well as the boundary value problems for the Laplace equation on a disk.)

- on the theoretical side, to know how the method of separation of variables is related to eigenvalue problems. (Rigorous proofs of convergence of the series of solutions should also be understood.)

- to learn well the solution of the Cauchy problem for the wave equations in low dimensions by the method of spherical means,

- to learn well the solution of the Cauchy problem for the heat equation by the heat kernel or by Fourier transform. The characteristic properties of heat flows and wave motions should be well-understood.

- to know the Poison formula for the solution of the Laplace equation on a ball and have some idea of solving the problem over a general domain by Perron’s method, and

- to understand well various maximum principle as they are applied to the uniqueness issues for elliptic and parabolic equations.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics are usually selected from: First-order equations, types of second-order equations, well-posedness of the wave and the heat equations, boundary value problems for the Laplace and Poisson equations, separation of variables.
courses.recommended_readings:
References (The first one is the main reference.)

- Partial Differential Equations An introduction, by W.A. Strauss, John-Wiley & Sons, New York. (Easy to read. Contain many standard materials and exercises.)

- A First Course in Partial Differential Equations with Complex and Transform Methods, by H. Weinberger, Dover Books on Mathematics. (This book is good source on separation of variables. Many work-out examples.)

- Partial Differential Equations, 4th ed. by F. John, Springer-Verlag, New York. (A classic by a master. But a little bit difficult to read.)

- Partial Differential Equations, by L.C. Evans, vol 19, Graduate Studies in Mathematics, American Mathematical Society, Providence. (Containing both linear and nonlinear theories, this is by far the best introductory book on PDE’s in postgraduate level. All proofs are rigorous and complete. The first several chapters can be read for good students in this class.)

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Optimization Theory
courses.description:
Unconstrained and equality optimization models, constrained problems, optimality conditions for constrained extrema, convex sets and functions, duality in nonlinear convex programming, descent methods, conjugate direction methods and quasi-Newton methods. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.course_syllabus: Unconstrained and equality optimization models, constrained problems, optimality conditions for constrained extrema, convex sets and functions, duality in nonlinear convex programming, descent methods, conjugate direction methods and quasi-Newton methods.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes

William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404

William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404

courses.description:
Bernoulli processes and sum of independent random variables, Poisson processes, times of arrivals, Markov chains, transient and recurrent states, stationary distribution of Markov chains, Markov pure jump processes, and birth and death processes. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in probability.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken IERG3300.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This is a second course in probability theory. We expect students to learn systems which vary in time in a random manner. In the course they will learn the use of probability and mathematics in the theory and to see many examples that are related to real life problems. The basic learning outcomes are:

- Students will be familiar with the basic probability notations: independence, conditioning, random variables, distributions, expected values, moments.

- Students learn the important concept of Markov chain, transition probability, hitting time, transient and recurrent states. They will learn the computation techniques in linear analysis, and examples like gambler’s ruin problem, birth and death chains, branching chains, queuing chains.

- Students learn the stationary distribution, existence and uniqueness, convergence and long time behavior, applications to real life problems.

- Students learn the continuous-time Markov chains, basic properties, generator of the chains, differential equation technique, Poisson processes, birth and death processes queuing chains.

- Students learn the Gaussian processes and Brownian motions.
courses.course_syllabus: Bernoulli processes and sum of independent random variables, Poisson processes, times of arrivals, Markov chains, transient and recurrent states, stationary distribution of Markov chains, Markov pure jump processes, and birth and death processes. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in probability.
courses.recommended_readings:
Main Reference:

- Introduction to Stochastic Processes, by P. Hoel, S. Port and C. Stone, Waveland Press

Other References:

- Essentials of Stochastic Processes, R. Durrett, Springer (many real life examples)

- Introduction to Stochastic Processes, G. Lawler, Chapman & Hall (more condense, a good book)

- Introduction to Stochastic Processes, E. Cinlar, Prentice Hall (detail in Bernoulli processes and Poisson processes)

- Basic Stochastic Processes, Z. Brzezniak andn T. Zastawniak, Springer (more rigorous mathematically)

- A Course in Probability, K.L. Chung, Academic Press (graduate text)

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Game Theory

meetings.location: Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall2
Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall2
Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall2

courses.description:
Principles and techniques of game theory, matrix games, minimax theorem and calculation of optimal strategies, cooperative and non-cooperative solutions of bimatrix games, coalitional games and applications. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in linear algebra.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
We expect the students to understand the mathematics and quantitative techniques behind the game theory. The theory will be illustrated by plenty of examples. Through this students will be exposed to practical problem decision making and in economics including optimization, bargaining, cooperation, coalition and voting strategies. The basic learning outcomes are:

- Students understand the basic step of games: the game tree, games with chances, information set, strategies, payoffs, equilibrium of strategies.

- Students learn the basic mathematics and examples in two person zero-sum games: saddle point, mixed strategy, minimax theorem. They need to sue matrix theory and linear programming to solve the problems.

- Students learn the non-zero sum games which includes cooperative, non-cooperative games, Nash’s equilibrium and Nash’s axiom of bargaining and the mathematics to attack these problems.

- Students learn the N-person cooperative games including strategy for coalition, Shapley value, voting games.
courses.course_syllabus: Principles and techniques of game theory, matrix games, minimax theorem and calculation of optimal strategies, cooperative and non-cooperative solutions of bimatrix games, coalitional games and applications.
courses.recommended_readings:
Main Reference:

- Introduction to game Theory, by P. Morris, Springer

Other References:

- Game Theory, by G. Owen, Saunder Co.

- The Shapley Value, Ed. By A. Roth, Cambridge U. Press

- Operations Research, An Introduction, by H. Taha, Macmillian

- The Foundation of Game Theory, vol. I, II, III, M. Dimand & R. Dimand, Edward Elgar Publ. Co.

- Classics in Game Theory, ed. By H. Kuhn, Princeton U. Press.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Coding Theory and Cryptography
courses.description:
Coding theory: information theory, linear codes, cyclic codes and geometric codes. Cryptography: classical cryptosystems and public key cryptosystems. Students taking this course are expected to have some knowledge in algebra and number theory.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.learning_outcomes:
We expect students to learn basic concepts and results in Coding and Cryptography. The basic outcomes are:

- Students learn the basic properties of entropy

- Students learn various inequalities relating entropy to channel coding

- Students learn the various notions of channel coding

- Students learn the Huffman encoding scheme

- Students learn the Noiseless Coding Theorem and its consequences

- Students learn the notion of block code

- Students learn the basic properties of linear code

- Students learn the concepts of generator matrix and parity check matrix, standard array and syndrome decoding and how to compute them

- Students learn some rudimentary properties of finite fields

- Students learn some elementary properties of cyclic codes

- Students learn some elementary cryptographic techniques
courses.course_syllabus: Coding theory: information theory, linear codes, cyclic codes and geometric codes. Cryptography: classical cryptosystems and public key cryptosystems.
courses.recommended_readings:
- P. Garrett, Mathematics for Coding Theory, Prentice Hall: information, compression, error correction, and finite fields, Pearson/Prentice-Hall

- S. Roman, Introduction to Coding and Information Theory, Springer-Verlag

- W. Trappe, L. Washington: Introduction to Cryptography, Prentice Hall, 2nd ed.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Innovation and Design in Big Data Analytics

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404

courses.description:
This course focuses on the applications of mathematical data analytic tools in a variety of science, medical, financial and engineering problems. Students will become familiar with mathematical tools and models for essential topics/case-studies selected from, but not limited to, algorithm trading, fraud detection, digital advertising, medical imaging, bioinformatics, remote sensing, and social networks. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in mathematical foundation of data analytics and related computational techniques.
Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: AIST1110 or CSCI 1020 or CSCI1110 or CSCI1120 or CSCI1130 or CSCI1510 or CSCI1520 or CSCI1530 or CSCI1540 or ESTR1100 or ESTR1102 or IERG1080 or MATH2221.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of this course, students will be able to:
• Analyze, evaluate, interpret, organize and synthesize information in a practical and quantitative manner.
• Understand in-depth the various problems and the technical difficulties in solving them.
• Apply sophisticated modelling and computational techniques to critically examine the problem and solution methods
• Critically evaluate the findings resulting from the application of the models and the techniques.
• Undertake an independent analysis of given data sets related to the problems using programming languages.
courses.course_syllabus: Cover a broad base of knowledge of big data analytics with in-depth mathematical analysis and skills development to tackle various practical problems, including, algorithm trading, fraud detection, digital advertising, medical imaging, bioinformatics, remote sensing, and social networks.
courses.required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Project

A project in pure or applied mathematics, either in research or in reviewing the literature of an advanced topic. Each section may be taken by an individual student or a team of two students. Prerequisite: permission of the instructor and satisfaction of at least one of the following conditions: 1) with Major GPA in the preceding academic term of at least 3.3; 2) with cumulative Major GPA of at least 3.3; and 3) any special case explicitly endorsed by the Board of the Department.

courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MATH4900. Pre-requisite: (MATH2050/2058 or MATH2060/2068) and MATH2221.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to demonstrate independence in advanced study or research. In addition, skills in communicating ideas and rigor are trained.
courses.course_syllabus: A project in pure or applied mathematics, either in research or in reviewing the literature of an advanced topic.
courses.recommended_readings: Articles and books are suggested by the supervising teacher according to the topic of study or research.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Real Analysis I
courses.description:
This course is an introduction to real analysis on abstract spaces. The following contents are covered: Integration on a measure space, the construction of measures from outer measures, Riesz representation theorem relating positive functionals to measures, Lebesque and Hausdorff measures, Lebesgue spaces and their duality, weak convergence of functions, signed measures and Radon-Nikodym theorem.
Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in Lebesgue integration on the real line and elements of functional analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics. Approval is needed for students in BSc Mathematics, BEd Mathematics and Mathematics Education or BSc Mathematics and Information Engineering.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To understand the modern theory of measure and integration and the functional properties of measurable functions.
2. To familiarize the skills in analysis.
3. To have prepared for written qualifying examinations in the subject of analysis in major research universities.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include the followings: Abstract measure theory and integration of measurable functions. Various fundamental theorems concerning convergence of integrals. Outer measures and the construction of a measure space from them. Riesz representation on a locally compact Hausdorff space. Lebesgue and Hausdorff measures on the Euclidean space. The Lebesgue spaces and their functional properties, uniform convexity and duality theorem. Weak convergence of functions. Signed measures, decomposition of measures and Radon-Nikodym theorem.
courses.required_readings: Chosen by instructor from the Recommended Readings below.
courses.recommended_readings:
- W. Rudin, Real and Complex Analysis, 3rd ed. W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill, New York 1966.
- L. C. Evans and R. F. Gariepy, Measure Theory and Fine Properties of Functions, revised ed. CRC Press 2015.
- E.M. Stein and R. Shakarchi, Real Analysis: Measure Theory, Integration and Hilbert Spaces, Princeton Lectures in Analysis, Princeton 2005.
- E. Hewitt and K. Stromberg, Real and Abstract Analysis, E. Hewitt and K. Stromberg, Graduate Texts in Mathematics, Springer-Verlag, New York 1975.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Real Analysis II
courses.description: This course is a sequel to MATH5011 Real Anlaysis I. It consists of two parts. In the first part we discuss various covering lemmas and their applications to differentiation theory, maximal operators, product measures, Fubini's theorem and applications, Fourier transform and the inversion theorem. The second part is an introduction to Sobolev spaces. Basic knowledge of these spaces is covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics. Approval is needed for students in BSc Mathematics, BEd Mathematics and Mathematics Education or BSc Mathematics and Information Engineering.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To understand advanced differentiation theory and Sobolev spaces.

2. To familiarize the skills in analysis.

3. To have prepared for written qualifying examinations in the subject of analysis in major research universities.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics are selected from the followings: Vitali’s and Besicovitich’s covering theorems, Radon-Nikodym derivatives, maximal operators, Lebesgue differentiation theorem, change of variables; product measures, Fubini’s theorem, various applications; Fourier transform, inversion theorem. It also includes Sobolev spaces, Sobolev inequality, Morrey’s estimate, embedding theorems, capacity and Hausdorff measure.
courses.required_readings: Chosen by instructor from the Recommended Readings below.
courses.recommended_readings:
- W. Rudin, Real and Complex Analysis, 3rd ed. W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill, New York 1966.

- L. C. Evans and R. F. Gariepy, Measure Theory and Fine Properties of Functions, revised ed. CRC Press 2015.

- E.M. Stein and R. Shakarchi, Real Analysis: Measure Theory, Integration and Hilbert Spaces, Princeton Lectures in Analysis, Princeton 2005.

- E. Hewitt and K. Stromberg, Real and Abstract Analysis, E. Hewitt and K. Stromberg, Graduate Texts in Mathematics, Springer-Verlag, New York 1975.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Theory of Partial Differential Equations I
courses.description: This is course is devoted to introducing fundamental theories on evolution equations. In particular, the course concentrates on the following types of evolution equations: second-order parabolic equations, second-order hyperbolic equations, system of conservations laws and some nonlinear wave equations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics, also available to undergraduate students majored in mathematics. Approval is needed for students in MSc Mathematics or MSc Math Education.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include the followings: Second-order parabolic equations, Second-order hyperbolic equations, Hyperbolic system of the first-order, Semigroup theory, System of conservation laws, Nonlinear wave equations and dispersive wave equations (such as KdV equations).
courses.required_readings:
1. Partial differential equations (2nd edition) by Lawrence C. Evans
2. Partial Differential Equations (Applied Mathematical Sciences, 1) by Fritz John
3. Partial Differential Equations I, II, III by Michael E. Taylor

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Theory of Partial Differential Equations II
courses.description:
This course covers the basic theory of partial differential equations equations with emphasis on elliptic equations of second order. Both the classical and modern approaches to these equations are discussed. The main concern is various a prior estimates which are useful in solving linear and nonlinear equations. Some geometric applications are included. It is suited for those who are interested
in analysis or geometry.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics. Approval is needed for students in BSc Mathematics, BEd Mathematics and Mathematics Education, BSc Mathematics and Information Engineering, MSc Mathematics or MSc Math Education.
courses.learning_outcomes: The basic elliptic theory enables students to understand research papers involving elliptic equations and geometric analysis as well as equips them with necessary tools to embark on their own research.
courses.course_syllabus:
Classic theory: Poisson equation and Newtonian potential, maximum principles, Schauder estimates, method of continuity. DeGorgi-Nash-Moser iteration, a priori estimates, regularity theory.
Modern theory: Sobolev spaces,$W^{2,p}$-estimates, regularity of weak solutions.
Selected applications to geometry including harmonic maps.
courses.required_readings:
F.H. Lin and Q. Han, Elliptic Differential Equations, CIMS Notes.
D. Gilbarg and N.S. Trudinger, Elliptic Differential Equations of Second order, 2nd ed. Springer-Verlag.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Complex Analysis I
courses.description: This course is intended to provide a solid and advanced training in the basic techniques and theorem of complex analysis. Topics include: properties of holomorphic functions, complex integration, conformal mappings, singularities and residues. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and elementary analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics. Approval is needed for students in BSc Mathematics, BEd Mathematics and Mathematics Education or BSc Mathematics and Information Engineering.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To recognize the definitions and properties of holomorphic functions.
2. To be ready for further studies in areas related to complex analysis, e.g. analytic number theory.
3. To have prepared for written qualifying examinations in the area of complex analysis for major research universities in the world.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include the followings: Complex numbers and functions; complex limits and differentiability; elementary examples; analytic functions; analytic functions as mapping; complex line integrals; Cauchy-Goursat theorem and integral formula; zeros of holomorphic functions; the Open Mapping theorem; Schwarz' Lemma; automorphisms of the ball, the plane and the Riemann sphere; isolated singularities and their classification; Laurent series; the Residue Theorem; the Argument principle; calculation of definite integrals and evaluation of infinite series using residues.
courses.required_readings: 1. John B Conway, Functions of One Complex Variable
courses.recommended_readings:
1. E.M. Stein and R. Shakarchi, Complex Analysis, Princeton University Press, 2003.
2. L Ahlfors, Complex Analysis, 3rd Ed., McGraw-Hill
3. W. Rudin, Real and Complex Analysis, 3rd ed. W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill, New York 1966.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Complex Analysis II
courses.description: This is a continuation of MAT5031/MATH5031; advanced topics in complex analysis will be selected from: Schwarz lemma, Riemann mapping theorem, Picard theorem, Weierstrass theorem and Mittag Leffler theorem, analytic continuation and introduction to Riemann surfaces. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and elementary analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics. Approval is needed for students in BSc Mathematics, BEd Mathematics and Mathematics Education or BSc Mathematics and Information Engineering.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To recognize further properties of holomorphic functions.
2. To be ready for further studies in areas related to complex analysis, e.g. analytic number theory.
3. To have prepared for written qualifying examinations in the area of complex analysis for major research universities in the world.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include the followings: The Maximum Modulus Theorem; Schwarz Lemma; Convex function and Hadamard's Three circle theorem; Lindelöf’s theorem; normal family; compactness in the space of analytic functions; Montel Theorem; Weierstrass theorem; Entire function and Hadarmard factorization Theorem; Gamma and Zeta function; Mittag Leffler theorem; Analytic continuation; Schwarz reflection Principle; Harmonic functions; Jensen's formula; Little Picard Theorem; Great Picard Theorem; Introduction to Riemann surface.
courses.required_readings: 1. John B Conway, Functions of One Complex Variable
courses.recommended_readings:
1. E.M. Stein and R. Shakarchi, Complex Analysis, Princeton University Press, 2003.
2. L Ahlfors, Complex Analysis, 3rd Ed., McGraw-Hill
3. W. Rudin, Real and Complex Analysis, 3rd ed. W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill, New York 1966.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Abstract Algebra I
courses.description: This course is intended to provide a comprehensive and solid foundation in abstract algebra. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in a first course in algebra.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics. Approval is needed for students in BSc Mathematics, BEd Mathematics and Mathematics Education or BSc Mathematics and Information Engineering.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To have a basic understanding of general abstract algebra
2. To be ready for graduate studies in algebra-related subjects such as algebraic geometry, number theory, representation theory, etc
3. To be prepared for written qualifying examinations in the area of algebra for major research universities in the world.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include group theory, series of groups, solvable and nilpotent groups, group actions, Sylow theorems, free groups, group presentations, ring theory, prime and maximal ideals, polynomial rings, factorization in rings, modules, structure of finitely generated modules over PIDs, field extensions, finite fields, Galois theory.
courses.required_readings: Chosen by instructor or selected from the Recommended Readings below.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. T. Hungerford, Algebra
2. M. Artin, Algebra
3. S. Lange, Algebra
4. D. Dummit and R. Foote, Abstract Algebra

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Abstract Algebra II
courses.description: This is a continuation of MATH5051. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in MATH5051 or equivalent..
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics. Approval is needed for students in BSc Mathematics, BEd Mathematics and Mathematics Education or BSc Mathematics and Information Engineering.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To have a deeper understanding of abstract algebra.
2. To be ready for studying research topics in algebra-related subjects such as algebraic geometry, number theory, representation theory, etc.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include cyclic extensions, Kummer theory, transcendental extensions, infinite Galois theory, integral ring extensions, Noetherian rings and modules, localization, Hilbert's basis theorem and Nullstellensatz, primary decomposition, Dedekind domains, basic homological algebra, representation theory of finite groups.
courses.required_readings: Chosen by instructor or selected from the Recommended Readings below.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. T. Hungerford, Algebra
2. M. Artin, Algebra
3. S. Lange, Algebra
4. D. Dummit and R. Foote, Abstract Algebra

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Riemannian Geometry I
courses.description: This course is intended to provide a solid background in Riemannian Geometry. Topics include: affine connection, tensor calculus, Riemannian metric, geodesics, curvature tensor, completeness and some global theory. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in differential geometry of curves and surfaces.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics. Approval is needed for students in BSc Mathematics, BEd Mathematics and Mathematics Education or BSc Mathematics and Information Engineering.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To recognize the definitions and properties of basic objects in Riemannian geometry (including metrics, tensors, geodesics, and curvatures)
2. To develop basic computational skill in Tensor calculus
3. To be ready for further studies related to Riemannian geometry.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include affine connection, tensor calculus, Riemannian metric, geodesics, curvature tensor, completeness and some global theory.
courses.required_readings: Chosen by instructor from the Recommended Readings below.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. S.S. Chern, W.H. Chen and K.S. Lam, Lectures on Differential Geometry, Series on University Mathematics Vol.1, World Scientific Publishing 1999
2. M. do Carmo, Riemannian Geometry, 1st edition, Springer 1992
3. S. Gallot, D. Hulin and J. Lafontaine, Riemannian Geometry, 3rd edition, Universitext, Springer 2004
4. J. Jost, Riemannian Geometry and Geometric Analysis, 7th edition, Universitext, Springer 2017
5. J. M. Lee, Introduction to Riemannian Manifolds, 2nd edition, Graduate Texts in Mathematics Vol. 176, Springer 2018
6. R. Schoen and S.T. Yau, Lectures on Differential Geometry, International Press 2010
7. P. Petersen, Riemannian Geometry, 3rd edition, Graduate Texts in Mathematics Vol. 171, Springer 2016
8. P. Li, Geometric Analysis, Cambridge University Press 2012
9. J. Cheeger and D. Ebin, Comparison Theorems in Riemannian Geometry, AMS Chelsea Publishing 2008

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Riemannian Geometry II
courses.description: This is a continuation of MATH5061; advanced topics in Riemannian Geometry will be selected from: comparison theorems, Bochner method, Hodge theory, submanifold theory and variational formulas. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in MATH5061 or equivalent.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics. Approval is needed for students in BSc Mathematics, BEd Mathematics and Mathematics Education or BSc Mathematics and Information Engineering.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To have basic knowledge of advance topics in Riemannian geometry (selected from: comparison theorems, Bochner method, variational formulae, Hodge theory)
2. To be ready for further studies related to geometric analysis
3. To have prepared for written qualifying examinations in the area of geometry for major research universities in the world.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics will be chosen by the instructor from (but not limited to) the following: comparison theorems, Bochner method, Hodge theory, submanifold theory and variational formulas.
courses.required_readings: Chosen by instructor from the Recommended Readings below.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. S.S. Chern, W.H. Chen and K.S. Lam, Lectures on Differential Geometry, Series on University Mathematics Vol.1, World Scientific Publishing 1999
2. M. do Carmo, Riemannian Geometry, 1st edition, Springer 1992
3. S. Gallot, D. Hulin and J. Lafontaine, Riemannian Geometry, 3rd edition, Universitext, Springer 2004
4. J. Jost, Riemannian Geometry and Geometric Analysis, 7th edition, Universitext, Springer 2017
5. J. M. Lee, Introduction to Riemannian Manifolds, 2nd edition, Graduate Texts in Mathematics Vol. 176, Springer 2018
6. R. Schoen and S.T. Yau, Lectures on Differential Geometry, International Press 2010
7. P. Petersen, Riemannian Geometry, 3rd edition, Graduate Texts in Mathematics Vol. 171, Springer 2016
8. P. Li, Geometric Analysis, Cambridge University Press 2012
9. J. Cheeger and D. Ebin, Comparison Theorems in Riemannian Geometry, AMS Chelsea Publishing 2008

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Topology of Manifolds
courses.description: This course is an introduction to several basic topological invariants for manifolds. Major topics are: topological and differentiable manifolds, maps between manifolds, Sard's Theorem, degree of maps and vector fields, fundamental group, covering space, simplices and homology group, differential forms and cohomology group. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis and basic topology and algebra.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics. Approval is needed for students in BSc Mathematics, BEd Mathematics and Mathematics Education or BSc Mathematics and Information Engineering.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To recognize the definitions and properties of several basic topological invariants for manifolds.
2. To be ready for further studies related to manifolds (smooth, Riemannian, or complex).
3. To have prepared for written qualifying examinations in the area of topology for major research universities in the world.
courses.course_syllabus: There may be several focus of the course, differential topology, or algebraic topology, or a more geometric approach. Topics are selected from the following. Topological and differentiable manifolds with or without boundary, tangent bundle and vector bundle and differential forms, mappings between manifolds and differentials, Sard’s Theorem, embedding and transversality, degree of maps and vector fields, homotopy, fundamental groups, covering spaces, singular homology or de Rham cohomology.
courses.required_readings: Chosen by instructor from the Recommended Readings below.
courses.recommended_readings:
- John Milnor. Topology from a Differentiable Point of View.
- Morris Hirsch. Differential Topology.
- John Lee. Introduction to Topological Manifolds.
- William Massey. A Basic Course in Algebraic Topology.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Advanced Numerical Analysis I
courses.description: This course covers basic numerical methods in the graduate level. The main themes are numerical solutions of PDEs and iterative methods for linear systems. For numerical solutions of PDEs, some basic theories of finite element methods for elliptic and parabolic equations are discussed. The topics include Sobolev spaces, embedding and trace theorems, variational formulation, Lax-Milgram theorem, finite element spaces and their interpolation theories, convergence in H1 and L2 norms. For iterative methods for linear systems, the topics include Richardson, Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel and SOR methods, Krylov subspace methods, conjugate gradient method, preconditioning techniques, convergence theories, GMRES method.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MPhil-PhD Mathematics. Approval is needed for students in BSc Mathematics, BEd Mathematics and Mathematics Education or BSc Mathematics and Information Engineering.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to learn the basic theories of finite element method for PDE and some classical iterative methods for linear algebraic and eigenvalue problems. The learning outcomes are
- Students learn some theories of Sobolev spaces.
- Students learn some embedding and trace theorems.
- Students learn how to derive the variational formulation of PDE.
- Students learn how to prove existence and uniqueness of variational problems by the use of Lax-Milgram theorem.
- Students learn how to construct finite element spaces and obtain the corresponding interpolation error estimates.
- Students learn how to prove convergence of finite element methods in H1 and L2 norms.
- Students learn some basic iterative methods including Richardson, Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel and SOR methods, and their convergence theories.
- Students learn Krylov subspace methods.
- Students learn the conjugate gradient method and its convergence theory.
- Students learn some preconditioning techniques for iterative methods.
- Students learn the GMRES method and its convergence theory.
courses.course_syllabus: The topics include Sobolev spaces, embedding and trace theorems, variational formulation, Lax-Milgram theorem, finite element spaces and their interpolation theories, convergence in H1 and L2 norms. For iterative methods for linear systems, the topics include Richardson, Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel and SOR methods, Krylov subspace methods, conjugate gradient method, preconditioning techniques, convergence theories, GMRES method.
courses.required_readings:
- Claes Johnson, Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations by the Finite Element Method, Dover Publications
- Gene Golub and Charles Van Loan, Matrix Computations, Johns Hopkins University Press
courses.recommended_readings:
- Dietrich Braess, Finite Elements: Theory, Fast Solvers and Applications in Solid Mechanics, Cambridge University Press
- Lloyd N. Trefethen and David Bau III, Numerical Linear Algebra, Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Advanced Numerical Analysis II
courses.description: This course covers basic numerical methods in the graduate level. The main themes are numerical solutions of PDEs and numerical methods for eigenvalue problems. For numerical solutions of PDEs, some basic theories of finite difference methods for hyperbolic equations are discussed. The topics include stability, order of accuracy, consistency, Lax-equivalence theorem, multistep methods, dissipation and dispersion, system of equations in higher dimensions, splitting schemes. For numerical methods for eigenvalue problems, the topics include the Gershgorin theorem, power iteration, inverse power iteration, Householder and Givens matrices, QR factorization, QR algorithm, singular value decomposition, principle component analysis, rank deficient problems, regularization techniques.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MPhil-PhD Mathematics. Approval is needed for students in BSc Mathematics, BEd Mathematics and Mathematics Education or BSc Mathematics and Information Engineering.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to learn the basic theories of finite difference method for PDE as well as some classical iterative methods for linear algebraic and eigenvalue problems. The learning outcomes are
- Students learn how to construct finite difference schemes for hyperbolic PDE.
- Students learn how to analyze the stability by the Fourier method.
- Students learn how to prove convergence and consistency.
- Students learn how to construct multistep methods.
- Students learn how to analyze dissipation and dispersion.
- Students learn how to construct and analyze schemes for hyperbolic systems in multi-dimensions.
- Students learn how to construct and analyze splitting schemes.
- Students learn some basic iterative method for eigenvalue problems, including power and inverse power iteration, as well as QR algorithm.
- Students learn how to compute the Householder and Givens matrices, QR factorization and singular value decomposition, together with their applications.
- Students learn the theory and applications of principle component analysis.
- Students learn how to solve rank deficient problems and their regularization techniques..
courses.course_syllabus: The topics include stability, order of accuracy, consistency, Lax-equivalence theorem, multistep methods, dissipation and dispersion, system of equations in higher dimensions, splitting schemes. For numerical methods for eigenvalue problems, the topics include the Gershgorin theorem, power iteration, inverse power iteration, Householder and Givens matrices, QR factorization, QR algorithm, singular value decomposition, principle component analysis, rank deficient problems, regularization techniques.
courses.required_readings:
- Morton and Mayers, Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations: An Introduction, Cambridge University Press
- Gene Golub and Charles Van Loan, Matrix Computations, Johns Hopkins University Press
courses.recommended_readings:
- John C. Strikwerda, Finite Difference Schemes and Partial Differential Equations, Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics
- Lloyd N. Trefethen and David Bau III, Numerical Linear Algebra, Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Topics in Representation Theory
courses.description: This course is intended to provide a brief, but solid, modern introduction to various topics in representation theory.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are able to: Define and distinguish the core concepts of classical representation theory, prove some of the fundamental theorems of classical representation theory and apply modern geometric and categorical methods to contemporary problems of representation theory.
courses.course_syllabus:
Representation theory of complex reductive groups and Lie algebras : root systems, highest weight theory, character formulae, Harish-Chandra modules, Verma modules and the BBG category O.
Representation theory of symmetric groups and Hecke algebras, and (optionally) affine Hecke algebras and W-algebras.
Geometric methods: aspects of Borel-Bott-Weil theory, Springer theory, Deligne-Lusztig Theory, Beilinson-Bernstein Localisation, Geometric Satake correspondence, Character sheaves and Quivers.
(Optionally) Representations of quantum groups, loop groups and quantum integrable systems, or alternatively reductive groups in finite characteristic, p-adic groups and finite groups of Lie type.
courses.required_readings:
"Representation Theory and Complex Geometry", Neil Chriss and Victor Ginzburg. Modern Birkhäuser Classics
"Representations of Semisimple Lie Algebras in the BGG Category O", James E. Humphreys. Graduate Studies in Mathematics Volume 94
"Representation Theory: A First Course", William Fulton and Joe Harris, Graduate Texts in Mathematics 129.
courses.recommended_readings:
"Representation Theory and Complex Geometry", Neil Chriss and Victor Ginzburg. Modern Birkhäuser Classics
"Representations of Semisimple Lie Algebras in the BGG Category O", James E. Humphreys. Graduate Studies in Mathematics Volume 94
"Representation Theory: A First Course", William Fulton and Joe Harris, Graduate Texts in Mathematics 129.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Topics in Mathematical Data Science
courses.description: Usually, more than one section with various topics selected from advanced applied mathematics will be offered. The selection of the topics depends on the field of interest of the instructor. This course will mainly focus on the understanding and application of mathematics in data science.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To understand the mordern theory of mathemaical data science.
2. To familiarize the skills in data sciences.
3. To have prepared for research in the subject of mathematical data science.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include the followings: Principal Component Analysis in High Dimensions; Graphs, Diffusion Maps, and Semi-supervised Learning; Spectral Clustering and Cheeger's Inequality; Concentration Inequalities; Johnson-Lindenstrauss Lemma and Gordon's Theorem; Compressed Sensing and Sparse Recovery; Community Detection and the Stochastic Block Model.
courses.required_readings: Ten Lectures and Forty-Two Open Problems in the Mathematics of Data Science, MIT 2015
courses.recommended_readings: High-dimensional probability: An introduction with applications in data science, Roman Vershynin, Cambridge University Press, 2018.

courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Topics in Probability Theory
courses.description: This course presents the modern probability theory based on the measure theory. In a first part, we introduce the probability space, random variable, different notions of convergence, law of large number, etc. In a second part, we present the theory of stochastic processes, including the martingale theory, the Brownian motion and Poisson process, and their link to the PDE.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics
courses.learning_outcomes: To understand some classical results in the probability and stochastic processes theory. To familiarize the skills in probabilty theory.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I : Probability space, random variable, expectation, independence, convergence of random variables, law of large number, central limit theorem.
Part II : Conditional expectation, martingale, Brownian motion and the heat equation, Poisson process and integro-differential equation.
courses.required_readings:
Chosen by instructor from the Recommended Readings below.

K. L. Chung, A course in probability theory. Elsevier Inc., 1968.
Rick Durrett, Probability: Theory and Examples, Cambridge Series in Statistical and Probabilistic Mathematics, Version 5, 2019.
courses.recommended_readings:
K. L. Chung, A course in probability theory. Elsevier Inc., 1968.
Rick Durrett, Probability: Theory and Examples, Cambridge Series in Statistical and Probabilistic Mathematics, Version 5, 2019.
